urn:contentItem:5VMR-MK41-DY7X-Y321-00000-00Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D), Presidential Candidate is Interviewed on MSNBC.2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisSen. Elizabeth Warren (D), Presidential Candidate is Interviewed on MSNBC.

Subject: Politics

Participants: Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D), Presidential Candidate; Mika Brzezinski, MSNBC Anchor;

Time: 09:19:00

Date: 2019-03-13

MIKA BRZEZINSKI, MSNBC ANCHOR: And let's, right away, bring in Democratic Presidential Candidate Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.

I have Willie with me, but I'll start things out.

I'd like to try something different --

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: Because you're one of the few candidates with a really significant, clear message that you have lived throughout your life and you have worked for the same issues, on the same issues since you were in college, in graduate school. And I love that. So I want to ask you some questions about other issues that would -- you would confront as president. Rapid-fire.

WARREN: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: So just your gut. Your gut on these core things.

So, as a parent, how much sympathy would you have for these parents who are embroiled in this alleged cheating scandal?

WARREN: Zero.

BRZEZINSKI: Zero. OK.

Would "President Warren" ground the 737 Max 8 right now?

WARREN: Yes.

BRZEZINSKI: Absolutely.

Is Brexit good for the U.S. and why?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: Why?

WARREN: Because having our close ally, Great Britain, in such economic turmoil is not helpful to us. We need our allies to be strong.

BRZEZINSKI: How would "President Elizabeth Warren" neutralize the North Korean nuclear and missile programs when the last four presidents have not been able to do so?

WARREN: Boy, it is a tough one and we just have to start out by acknowledging that. But the first thing you do, is you don't head off to a summit without doing your homework.

The tough part has got to be sitting down with the North Koreans. And it's the pain-staking work of diplomacy where you figure out what it is that they need, what it is that we can supply, how many allies we can pull into this to bring pressure on North Korea. The idea of simply giving away to North Korea what they want, which is the big photo-op with the president of the United States, and get the president of the United States to say what China has always wanted them to say about how provocative it is that we're doing military exercises with our allies, the South Koreans and the Japanese, is just giving things up without getting anything in return. I guarantee that's not a path to success.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes, there wasn't a -- it doesn't appear that there was a lot of advance work for these summits.

WARREN: You know, and that's the problem. You can't walk into these things and somehow think that a personality, an eye-to-eye and sending love letters is going to take care of it. It's hard work.

BRZEZINSKI: Is Saudi Arabia and ally of the United States?

WARREN: Well, it is officially an ally of the United States, but it is an ally where I think we really have to keep pushing on this relationship. Right now it's engaged in a war in Yemen that the United States has gotten itself deeply threaded into without any authorization from Congress.

In addition, the killing of a journalist is just a reminder that Saudi Arabia is a government right now that does not believe in accountability. You know, that's the job of the journalist, is to hold people -- hold officials accountable. And they wipe one out and so far the response of the Trump administration has been nothing.

BRZEZINSKI: So what would be your public position on Saudi Arabia right now? What would you be saying and telegraphing?

WARREN: So -- so it's both halfs. The killing of Khashoggi is absolutely unacceptable. There needs to be some accountability in the government for that.

But the second would also be to say no on Yemen. We are not going to supply arms. We're not going to be helpful for them for a war in Yemen.

Yemen is now one of the biggest manmade humanitarian crises of the last half century. And the United States plays a role in this through its ally, Saudi Arabia. For a long time we were actually helping them pick bombing sights even. We refueled their airplanes. We've sold them the weapons. We're working hand in glove with them in a war we have no business being part of.

BRZEZINSKI: Can you name one, two or three Pentagon programs that you think could be eliminated?

WARREN: Hmm, that's interesting --

BRZEZINSKI: That's a good one. That's a tricker.

WARREN: Yes, it is. And I have to think about what -- what the programs are. But let me -- can I describe it this way and tell you what the --

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The range is?

We have to stop the Pentagon from building the best possible 20th century military and urge the Pentagon over to the 21st century military. And here's my example of that.

A lot of new tech. A lot of new cyber. The 21st century threats and the 21st century responses are not places where a 20th century military has real strength. It's much more about conventional weapons and large armies and so on and, you know, the ability to engage in lots of shooting wars around the world.

And the problem kind of coherent problem at the Pentagon is that there's always somebody in the room to defend an existing program, no matter how old it is, no matter how much circumstances have changed. Somebody is at the head of that program. Somebody hands out the dollars to the defense industry that supports that program.

There's rarely somebody in the room for the next idea, for the place we need to be. And yet to have an effective military, we've got to be on the front edge, not the back edge, of development.

So I can tell you where I'd spend a lot more money, it's only a very small part of the Pentagon budget, is on research, it's on development, it's on cyber. That's the place we've got to get the Pentagon more focused in that direction.

BRZEZINSKI: Back to rapid-fire.

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: What has Donald Trump done that you think could be considered impeachable?

WARREN: Oh, come on now. No, but here's -- here's my rule on this one.

BRZEZINSKI: OK.

WARREN: We're about to get the Mueller report. And --

BRZEZINSKI: Back up.

WARREN: We have a lot of other information. Let's wait until we've got the Mueller report, combine it with everything else we've seen, then we'll know what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: So you agree with Nancy Pelosi's approach on this?

WARREN: I'm not sure where Nancy is when she says --

BRZEZINSKI: Well, she said he's not worth it at that point. So divisive.

WARREN: No. It's -- that's not the point. What I see is that the Mueller report is coming. Let's all take a look at the Mueller report. And when the Mueller report comes, we'll know exactly what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: What was wrong, if anything, with the statements that Representative Ilhan Omar made about Israel?

WARREN: You know, the way I see it is that we should -- we are a great deliberative body in Congress. And it is important for us to be able to debate issues, to do so respectfully. Any anti-Semitism or Islamophobia should be called out and condemned. But when should encourage our members --

BRZEZINSKI: So what she said were troupes and they were not worth --

WARREN: Well, when she'd doing that, then -- then that's a problem. But the -- but here's -- here's the part I -- I really want to make strongly. We've got to be a place that can have robust discussion. Not anti-Semitism, not Islamophobia, but robust discussion. And that's what we need to have.

BRZEZINSKI: What is it about Bernie Sanders that makes him so popular with progressives?

WARREN: You know, because he fights for what he believes in. Bernie and I have been friends forever and ever.

BRZEZINSKI: Bernie's at the top of the list in these polls right now --

WARREN: That's right.

BRZEZINSKI: Except for Biden, if he runs.

WARREN: That's right. But, you know, I've been friends with Bernie from long, long before I ever ended up in politics. And Bernie's out there fighting for what he believes in. And I think that -- that means a lot to people.

BRZEZINSKI: All right, two -- two more.

Is Mike Pence an honorable man?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. Would you like to expound upon that?

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: Anyone who engages in the kind of homophobia and attacks on people who are different from himself is not an honorable person. That's not -- that's not what honorable people do.

BRZEZINSKI: Should Bill Clinton have left office after having an affair with a much younger staffer in the White House?

WARREN: I don't know. I can't go back and litigate the 1990s. That one -- that one is beyond me.

BRZEZINSKI: Did the 1990s get us here, though, to an extent?

WARREN: Of course it did. And -- but I don't have the time machine to go back and change the '90s. All I can do is change this world going forward.

BRZEZINSKI: OK, Willie Geist, you can take over from here.

Willie.

WARREN: Go, Willie.

WILLIE GEIST, MSNBC CO-HOST: OK, senator, good to see you, as always.

I want to ask you about your "Medium" post last week --

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Where you talked about the breakup of big tech. The headline is, it's time to break up Amazon, Google and FaceBook. I think your argument was a little more nuance perhaps in the headline. Can you explain what you meant there?

WARREN: Sure. Let's use the example of Amazon. Amazon runs two kinds of businesses. One is it runs a platform. And that's the place where all the small businesses come and they trade and they -- buyer and sellers meet. And Amazon runs that platform, but also sucks out tons of information from every single transaction.

It then uses that information that nobody else is privy to, to look out and say, oh, there's a profitable business. We think we'll go into competition with them. And so it then puts out a product in competition with the pillow sales guy and then moves the profitable business back to page six and puts Amazon right at the front, Amazon's own business.

So, the way I see this, it's a little like baseball. We'll use a baseball analogy here. You can be the umpire, that's the platform, or you can have a team in the game, that's running these individual businesses that meet on the platform. But you don't get to do both simultaneously. So I think those ought to be broken apart.

GEIST: So another way to explain that too is let's take Apple. Obviously a very popular company. It has an app store.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Do you believe that Apple should be allowed to sell its own apps on its app store?

WARREN: So it needs to do one or the other. Either it runs that platform, the app store, or it's selling its own products on the app store, but it doesn't do both of those simultaneously because whenever it does, it has this enormous competitive advantage that wipes out all the other little businesses. In fact, did you know, Willie, that it's now referred to, this zone around folks like Apple and Google and Amazon, anyone that moves into the competition space, it's called the kill zone. And venture capitalists are investing about 20 percent less than they used to on these start-up companies because they know if they go into the kill zone, one of two things will happen. They'll either get gobbled up by the giant or they'll get wiped out by the giant, but they won't have a chance to grow and develop into what they might have been.

GEIST: So do you believe that Google, Amazon and FaceBook all are monopolies by your definition?

WARREN: Oh, I -- let's put it this way, they are huge. They have market dominance and they behave like monopolists. And that's a big part of the reason they need to be broken apart.

Look at -- look at what happened with FaceBook. I don't know about you, but a lot of people are really uneasy about how FaceBook handles their data.

GEIST: Yes.

WARREN: So, along comes What's App, right? And What's App says, I tell you what we'll do, we'll give a whole lot better protection for your privacy. And you watch a bunch of people move from FaceBook over to What's App. Now, that puts FaceBook in the position of doing one of two things, either they have to get better to meet the competition, that's what a good, robust market is all about, or, if you're already huge and dominate the field, just buy the competition and take their data. FaceBook, of course, chose to do the latter. They shouldn't be allowed to do that. That is not furthering competition.

You know, Willie, I believe in markets, but it's when markets have rules, when markets have a cops on the beat to make sure that the giants aren't gobbling up everyone else and eliminating competition. That's when markets work.

GEIST: So would you have worked to stop, in 2012, FaceBook purchase of Instagram?

WARREN: Yes. And we can -- here's the thing. We can go back and still do it. It's possible to go back under anti-trust laws and just say, look, we let this merger go through. Often the mergers are on conditions, conditional that they're not going to do this or they're not going to do that, but let the merger go through and look at it and say, it turns out it has anti-competitive effects. And if it has anti-competitive effects, then we can go back and unwind these and break these pieces apart.

Understand, for anybody who still wants to go on FaceBook and check out their old college roommates or anyone who still wants to go to Amazon and price out 46 coffee makers and get the one that can be delivered in 24 hours, or anybody who wants to go on Google and check out the capital of North Dakota, that will all still be possible. The platforms will still be there. What will be different is that the companies that are selling on those platforms will be in a real marketplace where they compete straight up based on price and service and quality of goods, not having the platform owner able to come in and have this enormous advantage to be able to scoop up all the business and kill off the little businesses, the entrepreneurs and the start-ups.

GEIST: You know, as you know well, senator, there's been this tension during the presidential campaign and it's come from comments from members of your party who are not running for president in many cases about capitalism versus socialism. And I've been interested to hear you say time and again and one -- you said I'm a capitalist to the bone. You were asked just on Sunday by John Heilemann on the circus (ph) if you were a capitalist. You said, yes, I'm a capitalist.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: We know how you feel about new government programs, things you're going to add there.

How do you explain where you are on the question of capitalism/socialism and where do they marry each other?

WARREN: So, look, I believe in markets. That's where this whole point about tech is all about. I see the benefits that markets can produce. I love the fact that there are a zillion people out there developing new apps or starting new businesses or trying a second one. I think that's fabulous. I think it's great that little businesses are trying to get to be medium sized businesses and medium sized businesses are trying to get to be large businesses.

But, understand this, markets without rules are theft. And there's got to be rules and there's got to be a cop on the beat.

You and I go a long way back. You remember back before the crash that what had happened basically was the financial giants had figured out they could make buckets of money by cheating their customers, mortgages, credit cards. And, sure enough, that's what they were doing. The cops on the beat, the regulators, just looked the other way, paid no attention. And the consequence was, big banks made a lot of money. They broke the backs of millions of families and ultimately crashed our economy. That's why we needed rules.

So, I came in with the idea of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. We got that bureau in place. And now you begin to see a much more level playing field. When there's a cop on the beat, those markets start to work again and banks, in that case, are forced to develop their profit models, not on cheating people, but on actually offering a better product.

Now, Wells Fargo proves they're still willing to get out there and try to cheat people, but at least we had some cops who caught them and have hauled them in and are trying to make changes in the company. That's what it takes. Markets have a lot to produce, but only if they have rules and if they have a cop that's enforcing those rules.

GEIST: So, senator, despite its flaws, some of which you've laid out there, do you believe capitalism over the course of history has been a force for good?

WARREN: So I -- yes, I do. I think it also, when -- when it doesn't work, it's been a force for bad, but that's been true of every form of government that we can identify, that we've gotten it right sometimes and gotten it wrong sometimes. When you let markets work with rules and with people on the beat to enforce those rules, we can produce a lot of wealth in this country. That's what we've done for a very long time. We have to recognize there are areas where markets don't work.

Health care, for example. Somebody having a heart attack is not somebody who's going to shop around to six different emergency rooms and say, which one is going to give me the best price?

Their -- education. Public education. That's not a place where a market works.

But there are places where markets do work. Coffee makers, pet pillows. I'm in. We need robust markets for those. That's how we produce.

By the way, that's how we ended up producing the Amazon's and Googles and FaceBooks of the world is the fact that markets could grow these incredible, incredible businesses.

BRZEZINSKI: So let me close by asking you, a lot of people seem to think the Democrats are most interested in having someone who can beat Trump and Trump is a street fighter and he plays by unfair rules. I feel like, just my opinion here, that Hillary Clinton was a bit boxed in on the debate stage, especially on issues pertaining to misogyny and sexism. I just feel like it's -- it was an area where she was extremely uncomfortable.

How would nominee Elizabeth Warren handle President Trump on the debate stage? Would you call him out on his misogyny? Would you call him out on his treatment of women? Would you call him out on his record? And how would you fight back when he calls you names?

WARREN: So I'm not afraid --

BRZEZINSKI: I want to know what this looks like.

WARREN: OK. Let's start with, I am not afraid of anyone, and particularly not Donald Trump. People have told me, for most of my life, what's too hard to get done. And my response has always been to fight back. The consumer agency, right? So, after the big crash --

BRZEZINSKI: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau created by Elizabeth Warren.

WARREN: That's right. I -- I came in and said, we need this agency.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: You know what people in Washington said to me? They said two things. The first one is, that's a great idea. That would actually change the world.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The second is, don't do it. Don't even try because it's too hard. You won't be able to get it done. You'll be up against the banks. They'll spend millions of dollars a day lobbying against this thing. And you know what my response was, I just got in the fight. And I got in the fight and I stayed in the fight. And today the consumer agency is the law of the land.

BRZEZINSKI: Are you afraid to get into his fight and to get into his face when one needs to?

WARREN: Not even a little bit.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. All right, you've got it go, I know. You've got a train to catch.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, thank you very much. It's great to have you. Come back anytime.

WARREN: Oh, it's so good to be here.

A lot of new tech. A lot of new cyber. The 21st century threatsand the 21st century responses are not places where a 20th centurymilitary has real strength. It's much more about conventionalweapons and large armies and so on and, you know, the ability toengage in lots of shooting wars around the world.

And the problem kind of coherent problem at the Pentagon isthat there's always somebody in the room to defend an existingprogram, no matter how old it is, no matter how much circumstanceshave changed. Somebody is at the head of that program. Somebodyhands out the dollars to the defense industry that supports thatprogram.

There's rarely somebody in the room for the next idea, for theplace we need to be. And yet to have an effective military, we'vegot to be on the front edge, not the back edge, of development.

So I can tell you where I'd spend a lot more money, it's only avery small part of the Pentagon budget, is on research, it's ondevelopment, it's on cyber. That's the place we've got to get thePentagon more focused in that direction.

BRZEZINSKI: Back to rapid-fire.

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: What has Donald Trump done that you think could beconsidered impeachable?

WARREN: Oh, come on now. No, but here's -- here's my rule onthis one.

BRZEZINSKI: OK.

WARREN: We're about to get the Mueller report. And --

BRZEZINSKI: Back up.

WARREN: We have a lot of other information. Let's wait untilwe've got the Mueller report, combine it with everything else we'veseen, then we'll know what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: So you agree with Nancy Pelosi's approach on this?

WARREN: I'm not sure where Nancy is when she says --

BRZEZINSKI: Well, she said he's not worth it at that point. Sodivisive.

WARREN: No. It's -- that's not the point. What I see is thatthe Mueller report is coming. Let's all take a look at the Muellerreport. And when the Mueller report comes, we'll know exactly whatto do.

BRZEZINSKI: What was wrong, if anything, with the statementsthat Representative Ilhan Omar made about Israel?

WARREN: You know, the way I see it is that we should -- we area great deliberative body in Congress. And it is important for us tobe able to debate issues, to do so respectfully. Any anti-Semitismor Islamophobia should be called out and condemned. But when shouldencourage our members --

BRZEZINSKI: So what she said were troupes and they were notworth --

WARREN: Well, when she'd doing that, then -- then that's aproblem. But the -- but here's -- here's the part I -- I really wantto make strongly. We've got to be a place that can have robustdiscussion. Not anti-Semitism, not Islamophobia, but robustdiscussion. And that's what we need to have.

BRZEZINSKI: What is it about Bernie Sanders that makes him sopopular with progressives?

WARREN: You know, because he fights for what he believes in.Bernie and I have been friends forever and ever.

BRZEZINSKI: Bernie's at the top of the list in these pollsright now --

WARREN: That's right.

BRZEZINSKI: Except for Biden, if he runs.

WARREN: That's right. But, you know, I've been friends withBernie from long, long before I ever ended up in politics. AndBernie's out there fighting for what he believes in. And I thinkthat -- that means a lot to people.

BRZEZINSKI: All right, two -- two more.

Is Mike Pence an honorable man?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. Would you like to expound upon that?

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: Anyone who engages in the kind of homophobia andattacks on people who are different from himself is not an honorableperson. That's not -- that's not what honorable people do.

BRZEZINSKI: Should Bill Clinton have left office after havingan affair with a much younger staffer in the White House?

WARREN: I don't know. I can't go back and litigate the 1990s.That one -- that one is beyond me.

BRZEZINSKI: Did the 1990s get us here, though, to an extent?

WARREN: Of course it did. And -- but I don't have the timemachine to go back and change the '90s. All I can do is change thisworld going forward.

BRZEZINSKI: OK, Willie Geist, you can take over from here.

Willie.

WARREN: Go, Willie.

WILLIE GEIST, MSNBC CO-HOST: OK, senator, good to see you, asalways.

I want to ask you about your "Medium" post last week --

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Where you talked about the breakup of big tech. Theheadline is, it's time to break up Amazon, Google and FaceBook. Ithink your argument was a little more nuance perhaps in theheadline. Can you explain what you meant there?

WARREN: Sure. Let's use the example of Amazon. Amazon runs twokinds of businesses. One is it runs a platform. And that's the placewhere all the small businesses come and they trade and they -- buyerand sellers meet. And Amazon runs that platform, but also sucks outtons of information from every single transaction.

It then uses that information that nobody else is privy to, tolook out and say, oh, there's a profitable business. We think we'llgo into competition with them. And so it then puts out a product incompetition with the pillow sales guy and then moves the profitablebusiness back to page six and puts Amazon right at the front,Amazon's own business.

So, the way I see this, it's a little like baseball. We'll usea baseball analogy here. You can be the umpire, that's the platform,or you can have a team in the game, that's running these individualbusinesses that meet on the platform. But you don't get to do bothsimultaneously. So I think those ought to be broken apart.

GEIST: So another way to explain that too is let's take Apple.Obviously a very popular company. It has an app store.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Do you believe that Apple should be allowed to sell itsown apps on its app store?

WARREN: So it needs to do one or the other. Either it runs thatplatform, the app store, or it's selling its own products on the appstore, but it doesn't do both of those simultaneously becausewhenever it does, it has this enormous competitive advantage thatwipes out all the other little businesses. In fact, did you know,Willie, that it's now referred to, this zone around folks like Appleand Google and Amazon, anyone that moves into the competition space,it's called the kill zone. And venture capitalists are investingabout 20 percent less than they used to on these start-up companiesbecause they know if they go into the kill zone, one of two thingswill happen. They'll either get gobbled up by the giant or they'llget wiped out by the giant, but they won't have a chance to grow anddevelop into what they might have been.

GEIST: So do you believe that Google, Amazon and FaceBook allare monopolies by your definition?

WARREN: Oh, I -- let's put it this way, they are huge. Theyhave market dominance and they behave like monopolists. And that's abig part of the reason they need to be broken apart.

Look at -- look at what happened with FaceBook. I don't knowabout you, but a lot of people are really uneasy about how FaceBookhandles their data.

GEIST: Yes.

WARREN: So, along comes What's App, right? And What's App says,I tell you what we'll do, we'll give a whole lot better protectionfor your privacy. And you watch a bunch of people move from FaceBookover to What's App. Now, that puts FaceBook in the position of doingone of two things, either they have to get better to meet thecompetition, that's what a good, robust market is all about, or, ifyou're already huge and dominate the field, just buy the competitionand take their data. FaceBook, of course, chose to do the latter.They shouldn't be allowed to do that. That is not furtheringcompetition.

You know, Willie, I believe in markets, but it's when marketshave rules, when markets have a cops on the beat to make sure thatthe giants aren't gobbling up everyone else and eliminatingcompetition. That's when markets work.

GEIST: So would you have worked to stop, in 2012, FaceBookpurchase of Instagram?

WARREN: Yes. And we can -- here's the thing. We can go back andstill do it. It's possible to go back under anti-trust laws and justsay, look, we let this merger go through. Often the mergers are onconditions, conditional that they're not going to do this or they'renot going to do that, but let the merger go through and look at itand say, it turns out it has anti-competitive effects. And if it hasanti-competitive effects, then we can go back and unwind these andbreak these pieces apart.

Understand, for anybody who still wants to go on FaceBook andcheck out their old college roommates or anyone who still wants togo to Amazon and price out 46 coffee makers and get the one that canbe delivered in 24 hours, or anybody who wants to go on Google andcheck out the capital of North Dakota, that will all still bepossible. The platforms will still be there. What will be differentis that the companies that are selling on those platforms will be ina real marketplace where they compete straight up based on price andservice and quality of goods, not having the platform owner able tocome in and have this enormous advantage to be able to scoop up allthe business and kill off the little businesses, the entrepreneursand the start-ups.

GEIST: You know, as you know well, senator, there's been thistension during the presidential campaign and it's come from commentsfrom members of your party who are not running for president in manycases about capitalism versus socialism. And I've been interested tohear you say time and again and one -- you said I'm a capitalist tothe bone. You were asked just on Sunday by John Heilemann on thecircus (ph) if you were a capitalist. You said, yes, I'm acapitalist.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: We know how you feel about new government programs,things you're going to add there.

How do you explain where you are on the question ofcapitalism/socialism and where do they marry each other?

WARREN: So, look, I believe in markets. That's where this wholepoint about tech is all about. I see the benefits that markets canproduce. I love the fact that there are a zillion people out theredeveloping new apps or starting new businesses or trying a secondone. I think that's fabulous. I think it's great that littlebusinesses are trying to get to be medium sized businesses andmedium sized businesses are trying to get to be large businesses.

But, understand this, markets without rules are theft. Andthere's got to be rules and there's got to be a cop on the beat.

You and I go a long way back. You remember back before thecrash that what had happened basically was the financial giants hadfigured out they could make buckets of money by cheating theircustomers, mortgages, credit cards. And, sure enough, that's whatthey were doing. The cops on the beat, the regulators, just lookedthe other way, paid no attention. And the consequence was, big banksmade a lot of money. They broke the backs of millions of familiesand ultimately crashed our economy. That's why we needed rules.

So, I came in with the idea of the Consumer FinancialProtection Bureau. We got that bureau in place. And now you begin tosee a much more level playing field. When there's a cop on the beat,those markets start to work again and banks, in that case, areforced to develop their profit models, not on cheating people, buton actually offering a better product.

Now, Wells Fargo proves they're still willing to get out thereand try to cheat people, but at least we had some cops who caughtthem and have hauled them in and are trying to make changes in thecompany. That's what it takes. Markets have a lot to produce, butonly if they have rules and if they have a cop that's enforcingthose rules.

GEIST: So, senator, despite its flaws, some of which you'velaid out there, do you believe capitalism over the course of historyhas been a force for good?

WARREN: So I -- yes, I do. I think it also, when -- when itdoesn't work, it's been a force for bad, but that's been true ofevery form of government that we can identify, that we've gotten itright sometimes and gotten it wrong sometimes. When you let marketswork with rules and with people on the beat to enforce those rules,we can produce a lot of wealth in this country. That's what we'vedone for a very long time. We have to recognize there are areaswhere markets don't work.

Health care, for example. Somebody having a heart attack is notsomebody who's going to shop around to six different emergency roomsand say, which one is going to give me the best price?

Their -- education. Public education. That's not a place wherea market works.

But there are places where markets do work. Coffee makers, petpillows. I'm in. We need robust markets for those. That's how weproduce.

By the way, that's how we ended up producing the Amazon's andGoogles and FaceBooks of the world is the fact that markets couldgrow these incredible, incredible businesses.

BRZEZINSKI: So let me close by asking you, a lot of people seemto think the Democrats are most interested in having someone who canbeat Trump and Trump is a street fighter and he plays by unfairrules. I feel like, just my opinion here, that Hillary Clinton was abit boxed in on the debate stage, especially on issues pertaining tomisogyny and sexism. I just feel like it's -- it was an area whereshe was extremely uncomfortable.

How would nominee Elizabeth Warren handle President Trump onthe debate stage? Would you call him out on his misogyny? Would youcall him out on his treatment of women? Would you call him out onhis record? And how would you fight back when he calls you names?

WARREN: So I'm not afraid --

BRZEZINSKI: I want to know what this looks like.

WARREN: OK. Let's start with, I am not afraid of anyone, andparticularly not Donald Trump. People have told me, for most of mylife, what's too hard to get done. And my response has always beento fight back. The consumer agency, right? So, after the big crash--

BRZEZINSKI: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau created byElizabeth Warren.

WARREN: That's right. I -- I came in and said, we need thisagency.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: You know what people in Washington said to me? Theysaid two things. The first one is, that's a great idea. That wouldactually change the world.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The second is, don't do it. Don't even try because it'stoo hard. You won't be able to get it done. You'll be up against thebanks. They'll spend millions of dollars a day lobbying against thisthing. And you know what my response was, I just got in the fight.And I got in the fight and I stayed in the fight. And today theconsumer agency is the law of the land.

BRZEZINSKI: Are you afraid to get into his fight and to getinto his face when one needs to?

WARREN: Not even a little bit.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. All right, you've got it go, I know. You've gota train to catch.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, thank you very much. It's great tohave you. Come back anytime.

WARREN: Oh, it's so good to be here.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VMR-XSB1-F15W-H18K-00000-00SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IS INTERVIEWED ON MSNBC.2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisSEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IS INTERVIEWED ON MSNBC.

March 13, 2019

NEWS PROGRAM

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

MIKA BRZEZINSKI, MSNBC ANCHOR: And let's, right away, bring in Democratic Presidential Candidate Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.

I have Willie with me, but I'll start things out.

I'd like to try something different --

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: Because you're one of the few candidates with a really significant, clear message that you have lived throughout your life and you have worked for the same issues, on the same issues since you were in college, in graduate school. And I love that. So I want to ask you some questions about other issues that would -- you would confront as president. Rapid-fire.

WARREN: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: So just your gut. Your gut on these core things.

So, as a parent, how much sympathy would you have for these parents who are embroiled in this alleged cheating scandal?

WARREN: Zero.

BRZEZINSKI: Zero. OK.

Would "President Warren" ground the 737 Max 8 right now?

WARREN: Yes.

BRZEZINSKI: Absolutely.

Is Brexit good for the U.S. and why?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: Why?

WARREN: Because having our close ally, Great Britain, in such economic turmoil is not helpful to us. We need our allies to be strong.

BRZEZINSKI: How would "President Elizabeth Warren" neutralize the North Korean nuclear and missile programs when the last four presidents have not been able to do so?

WARREN: Boy, it is a tough one and we just have to start out by acknowledging that. But the first thing you do, is you don't head off to a summit without doing your homework.

The tough part has got to be sitting down with the North Koreans. And it's the pain-staking work of diplomacy where you figure out what it is that they need, what it is that we can supply, how many allies we can pull into this to bring pressure on North Korea. The idea of simply giving away to North Korea what they want, which is the big photo-op with the president of the United States, and get the president of the United States to say what China has always wanted them to say about how provocative it is that we're doing military exercises with our allies, the South Koreans and the Japanese, is just giving things up without getting anything in return. I guarantee that's not a path to success.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes, there wasn't a -- it doesn't appear that there was a lot of advance work for these summits.

WARREN: You know, and that's the problem. You can't walk into these things and somehow think that a personality, an eye-to-eye and sending love letters is going to take care of it. It's hard work.

BRZEZINSKI: Is Saudi Arabia and ally of the United States?

WARREN: Well, it is officially an ally of the United States, but it is an ally where I think we really have to keep pushing on this relationship. Right now it's engaged in a war in Yemen that the United States has gotten itself deeply threaded into without any authorization from Congress.

In addition, the killing of a journalist is just a reminder that Saudi Arabia is a government right now that does not believe in accountability. You know, that's the job of the journalist, is to hold people -- hold officials accountable. And they wipe one out and so far the response of the Trump administration has been nothing.

BRZEZINSKI: So what would be your public position on Saudi Arabia right now? What would you be saying and telegraphing?

WARREN: So -- so it's both halfs. The killing of Khashoggi is absolutely unacceptable. There needs to be some accountability in the government for that.

But the second would also be to say no on Yemen. We are not going to supply arms. We're not going to be helpful for them for a war in Yemen.

Yemen is now one of the biggest manmade humanitarian crises of the last half century. And the United States plays a role in this through its ally, Saudi Arabia. For a long time we were actually helping them pick bombing sights even. We refueled their airplanes. We've sold them the weapons. We're working hand in glove with them in a war we have no business being part of.

BRZEZINSKI: Can you name one, two or three Pentagon programs that you think could be eliminated?

WARREN: Hmm, that's interesting --

BRZEZINSKI: That's a good one. That's a tricker.

WARREN: Yes, it is. And I have to think about what -- what the programs are. But let me -- can I describe it this way and tell you what the --

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The range is?

We have to stop the Pentagon from building the best possible 20th century military and urge the Pentagon over to the 21st century military. And here's my example of that.

A lot of new tech. A lot of new cyber. The 21st century threats and the 21st century responses are not places where a 20th century military has real strength. It's much more about conventional weapons and large armies and so on and, you know, the ability to engage in lots of shooting wars around the world.

And the problem kind of coherent problem at the Pentagon is that there's always somebody in the room to defend an existing program, no matter how old it is, no matter how much circumstances have changed. Somebody is at the head of that program. Somebody hands out the dollars to the defense industry that supports that program.

There's rarely somebody in the room for the next idea, for the place we need to be. And yet to have an effective military, we've got to be on the front edge, not the back edge, of development.

So I can tell you where I'd spend a lot more money, it's only a very small part of the Pentagon budget, is on research, it's on development, it's on cyber. That's the place we've got to get the Pentagon more focused in that direction.

BRZEZINSKI: Back to rapid-fire.

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: What has Donald Trump done that you think could be considered impeachable?

WARREN: Oh, come on now. No, but here's -- here's my rule on this one.

BRZEZINSKI: OK.

WARREN: We're about to get the Mueller report. And --

BRZEZINSKI: Back up.

WARREN: We have a lot of other information. Let's wait until we've got the Mueller report, combine it with everything else we've seen, then we'll know what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: So you agree with Nancy Pelosi's approach on this?

WARREN: I'm not sure where Nancy is when she says --

BRZEZINSKI: Well, she said he's not worth it at that point. So divisive.

WARREN: No. It's -- that's not the point. What I see is that the Mueller report is coming. Let's all take a look at the Mueller report. And when the Mueller report comes, we'll know exactly what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: What was wrong, if anything, with the statements that Representative Ilhan Omar made about Israel?

WARREN: You know, the way I see it is that we should -- we are a great deliberative body in Congress. And it is important for us to be able to debate issues, to do so respectfully. Any anti-Semitism or Islamophobia should be called out and condemned. But when should encourage our members --

BRZEZINSKI: So what she said were troupes and they were not worth --

WARREN: Well, when she'd doing that, then -- then that's a problem. But the -- but here's -- here's the part I -- I really want to make strongly. We've got to be a place that can have robust discussion. Not anti-Semitism, not Islamophobia, but robust discussion. And that's what we need to have.

BRZEZINSKI: What is it about Bernie Sanders that makes him so popular with progressives?

WARREN: You know, because he fights for what he believes in. Bernie and I have been friends forever and ever.

BRZEZINSKI: Bernie's at the top of the list in these polls right now --

WARREN: That's right.

BRZEZINSKI: Except for Biden, if he runs.

WARREN: That's right. But, you know, I've been friends with Bernie from long, long before I ever ended up in politics. And Bernie's out there fighting for what he believes in. And I think that -- that means a lot to people.

BRZEZINSKI: All right, two -- two more.

Is Mike Pence an honorable man?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. Would you like to expound upon that?

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: Anyone who engages in the kind of homophobia and attacks on people who are different from himself is not an honorable person. That's not -- that's not what honorable people do.

BRZEZINSKI: Should Bill Clinton have left office after having an affair with a much younger staffer in the White House?

WARREN: I don't know. I can't go back and litigate the 1990s. That one -- that one is beyond me.

BRZEZINSKI: Did the 1990s get us here, though, to an extent?

WARREN: Of course it did. And -- but I don't have the time machine to go back and change the '90s. All I can do is change this world going forward.

BRZEZINSKI: OK, Willie Geist, you can take over from here.

Willie.

WARREN: Go, Willie.

WILLIE GEIST, MSNBC CO-HOST: OK, senator, good to see you, as always.

I want to ask you about your "Medium" post last week --

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Where you talked about the breakup of big tech. The headline is, it's time to break up Amazon, Google and FaceBook. I think your argument was a little more nuance perhaps in the headline. Can you explain what you meant there?

WARREN: Sure. Let's use the example of Amazon. Amazon runs two kinds of businesses. One is it runs a platform. And that's the place where all the small businesses come and they trade and they -- buyer and sellers meet. And Amazon runs that platform, but also sucks out tons of information from every single transaction.

It then uses that information that nobody else is privy to, to look out and say, oh, there's a profitable business. We think we'll go into competition with them. And so it then puts out a product in competition with the pillow sales guy and then moves the profitable business back to page six and puts Amazon right at the front, Amazon's own business.

So, the way I see this, it's a little like baseball. We'll use a baseball analogy here. You can be the umpire, that's the platform, or you can have a team in the game, that's running these individual businesses that meet on the platform. But you don't get to do both simultaneously. So I think those ought to be broken apart.

GEIST: So another way to explain that too is let's take Apple. Obviously a very popular company. It has an app store.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Do you believe that Apple should be allowed to sell its own apps on its app store?

WARREN: So it needs to do one or the other. Either it runs that platform, the app store, or it's selling its own products on the app store, but it doesn't do both of those simultaneously because whenever it does, it has this enormous competitive advantage that wipes out all the other little businesses. In fact, did you know, Willie, that it's now referred to, this zone around folks like Apple and Google and Amazon, anyone that moves into the competition space, it's called the kill zone. And venture capitalists are investing about 20 percent less than they used to on these start-up companies because they know if they go into the kill zone, one of two things will happen. They'll either get gobbled up by the giant or they'll get wiped out by the giant, but they won't have a chance to grow and develop into what they might have been.

GEIST: So do you believe that Google, Amazon and FaceBook all are monopolies by your definition?

WARREN: Oh, I -- let's put it this way, they are huge. They have market dominance and they behave like monopolists. And that's a big part of the reason they need to be broken apart.

Look at -- look at what happened with FaceBook. I don't know about you, but a lot of people are really uneasy about how FaceBook handles their data.

GEIST: Yes.

WARREN: So, along comes What's App, right? And What's App says, I tell you what we'll do, we'll give a whole lot better protection for your privacy. And you watch a bunch of people move from FaceBook over to What's App. Now, that puts FaceBook in the position of doing one of two things, either they have to get better to meet the competition, that's what a good, robust market is all about, or, if you're already huge and dominate the field, just buy the competition and take their data. FaceBook, of course, chose to do the latter. They shouldn't be allowed to do that. That is not furthering competition.

You know, Willie, I believe in markets, but it's when markets have rules, when markets have a cops on the beat to make sure that the giants aren't gobbling up everyone else and eliminating competition. That's when markets work.

GEIST: So would you have worked to stop, in 2012, FaceBook purchase of Instagram?

WARREN: Yes. And we can -- here's the thing. We can go back and still do it. It's possible to go back under anti-trust laws and just say, look, we let this merger go through. Often the mergers are on conditions, conditional that they're not going to do this or they're not going to do that, but let the merger go through and look at it and say, it turns out it has anti-competitive effects. And if it has anti-competitive effects, then we can go back and unwind these and break these pieces apart.

Understand, for anybody who still wants to go on FaceBook and check out their old college roommates or anyone who still wants to go to Amazon and price out 46 coffee makers and get the one that can be delivered in 24 hours, or anybody who wants to go on Google and check out the capital of North Dakota, that will all still be possible. The platforms will still be there. What will be different is that the companies that are selling on those platforms will be in a real marketplace where they compete straight up based on price and service and quality of goods, not having the platform owner able to come in and have this enormous advantage to be able to scoop up all the business and kill off the little businesses, the entrepreneurs and the start-ups.

GEIST: You know, as you know well, senator, there's been this tension during the presidential campaign and it's come from comments from members of your party who are not running for president in many cases about capitalism versus socialism. And I've been interested to hear you say time and again and one -- you said I'm a capitalist to the bone. You were asked just on Sunday by John Heilemann on the circus (ph) if you were a capitalist. You said, yes, I'm a capitalist.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: We know how you feel about new government programs, things you're going to add there.

How do you explain where you are on the question of capitalism/socialism and where do they marry each other?

WARREN: So, look, I believe in markets. That's where this whole point about tech is all about. I see the benefits that markets can produce. I love the fact that there are a zillion people out there developing new apps or starting new businesses or trying a second one. I think that's fabulous. I think it's great that little businesses are trying to get to be medium sized businesses and medium sized businesses are trying to get to be large businesses.

But, understand this, markets without rules are theft. And there's got to be rules and there's got to be a cop on the beat.

You and I go a long way back. You remember back before the crash that what had happened basically was the financial giants had figured out they could make buckets of money by cheating their customers, mortgages, credit cards. And, sure enough, that's what they were doing. The cops on the beat, the regulators, just looked the other way, paid no attention. And the consequence was, big banks made a lot of money. They broke the backs of millions of families and ultimately crashed our economy. That's why we needed rules.

So, I came in with the idea of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. We got that bureau in place. And now you begin to see a much more level playing field. When there's a cop on the beat, those markets start to work again and banks, in that case, are forced to develop their profit models, not on cheating people, but on actually offering a better product.

Now, Wells Fargo proves they're still willing to get out there and try to cheat people, but at least we had some cops who caught them and have hauled them in and are trying to make changes in the company. That's what it takes. Markets have a lot to produce, but only if they have rules and if they have a cop that's enforcing those rules.

GEIST: So, senator, despite its flaws, some of which you've laid out there, do you believe capitalism over the course of history has been a force for good?

WARREN: So I -- yes, I do. I think it also, when -- when it doesn't work, it's been a force for bad, but that's been true of every form of government that we can identify, that we've gotten it right sometimes and gotten it wrong sometimes. When you let markets work with rules and with people on the beat to enforce those rules, we can produce a lot of wealth in this country. That's what we've done for a very long time. We have to recognize there are areas where markets don't work.

Health care, for example. Somebody having a heart attack is not somebody who's going to shop around to six different emergency rooms and say, which one is going to give me the best price?

Their -- education. Public education. That's not a place where a market works.

But there are places where markets do work. Coffee makers, pet pillows. I'm in. We need robust markets for those. That's how we produce.

By the way, that's how we ended up producing the Amazon's and Googles and FaceBooks of the world is the fact that markets could grow these incredible, incredible businesses.

BRZEZINSKI: So let me close by asking you, a lot of people seem to think the Democrats are most interested in having someone who can beat Trump and Trump is a street fighter and he plays by unfair rules. I feel like, just my opinion here, that Hillary Clinton was a bit boxed in on the debate stage, especially on issues pertaining to misogyny and sexism. I just feel like it's -- it was an area where she was extremely uncomfortable.

How would nominee Elizabeth Warren handle President Trump on the debate stage? Would you call him out on his misogyny? Would you call him out on his treatment of women? Would you call him out on his record? And how would you fight back when he calls you names?

WARREN: So I'm not afraid --

BRZEZINSKI: I want to know what this looks like.

WARREN: OK. Let's start with, I am not afraid of anyone, and particularly not Donald Trump. People have told me, for most of my life, what's too hard to get done. And my response has always been to fight back. The consumer agency, right? So, after the big crash --

BRZEZINSKI: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau created by Elizabeth Warren.

WARREN: That's right. I -- I came in and said, we need this agency.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: You know what people in Washington said to me? They said two things. The first one is, that's a great idea. That would actually change the world.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The second is, don't do it. Don't even try because it's too hard. You won't be able to get it done. You'll be up against the banks. They'll spend millions of dollars a day lobbying against this thing. And you know what my response was, I just got in the fight. And I got in the fight and I stayed in the fight. And today the consumer agency is the law of the land.

BRZEZINSKI: Are you afraid to get into his fight and to get into his face when one needs to?

WARREN: Not even a little bit.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. All right, you've got it go, I know. You've got a train to catch.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, thank you very much. It's great to have you. Come back anytime.

WARREN: Oh, it's so good to be here.

END

urn:contentItem:5VMV-VTK1-DY0W-40JF-00000-00SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IS INTERVIEWED ON MSNBC.2019-03-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:13ZLexisNexisSEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IS INTERVIEWED ON MSNBC.LanhamFULL TEXT

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE IS INTERVIEWED ON MSNBC.

MARCH 13, 2019

SPEAKERS: SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE

MIKA BRZEZINSKI, MSNBC ANCHOR

[*] MIKA BRZEZINSKI, MSNBC ANCHOR: And let's, right away, bring inDemocratic Presidential Candidate Senator Elizabeth Warren ofMassachusetts.

I have Willie with me, but I'll start things out.

I'd like to try something different --

SEN. ELIZABETH WARREN (D), PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: Because you're one of the few candidates with areally significant, clear message that you have lived throughoutyour life and you have worked for the same issues, on the sameissues since you were in college, in graduate school. And I lovethat. So I want to ask you some questions about other issues thatwould -- you would confront as president. Rapid-fire.

WARREN: OK.

BRZEZINSKI: So just your gut. Your gut on these core things.

So, as a parent, how much sympathy would you have for theseparents who are embroiled in this alleged cheating scandal?

WARREN: Zero.

BRZEZINSKI: Zero. OK.

Would "President Warren" ground the 737 Max 8 right now?

WARREN: Yes.

BRZEZINSKI: Absolutely.

Is Brexit good for the U.S. and why?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: Why?

WARREN: Because having our close ally, Great Britain, in sucheconomic turmoil is not helpful to us. We need our allies to bestrong.

BRZEZINSKI: How would "President Elizabeth Warren" neutralizethe North Korean nuclear and missile programs when the last fourpresidents have not been able to do so?

WARREN: Boy, it is a tough one and we just have to start out byacknowledging that. But the first thing you do, is you don't headoff to a summit without doing your homework.

The tough part has got to be sitting down with the NorthKoreans. And it's the pain-staking work of diplomacy where youfigure out what it is that they need, what it is that we can supply,how many allies we can pull into this to bring pressure on NorthKorea. The idea of simply giving away to North Korea what they want,which is the big photo-op with the president of the United States,and get the president of the United States to say what China hasalways wanted them to say about how provocative it is that we'redoing military exercises with our allies, the South Koreans and theJapanese, is just giving things up without getting anything inreturn. I guarantee that's not a path to success.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes, there wasn't a -- it doesn't appear that therewas a lot of advance work for these summits.

WARREN: You know, and that's the problem. You can't walk intothese things and somehow think that a personality, an eye-to-eye andsending love letters is going to take care of it. It's hard work.

BRZEZINSKI: Is Saudi Arabia and ally of the United States?

WARREN: Well, it is officially an ally of the United States,but it is an ally where I think we really have to keep pushing onthis relationship. Right now it's engaged in a war in Yemen that theUnited States has gotten itself deeply threaded into without anyauthorization from Congress.

In addition, the killing of a journalist is just a reminderthat Saudi Arabia is a government right now that does not believe inaccountability. You know, that's the job of the journalist, is tohold people -- hold officials accountable. And they wipe one out andso far the response of the Trump administration has been nothing.

BRZEZINSKI: So what would be your public position on SaudiArabia right now? What would you be saying and telegraphing?

WARREN: So -- so it's both halfs. The killing of Khashoggi isabsolutely unacceptable. There needs to be some accountability inthe government for that.

But the second would also be to say no on Yemen. We are notgoing to supply arms. We're not going to be helpful for them for awar in Yemen.

Yemen is now one of the biggest manmade humanitarian crises ofthe last half century. And the United States plays a role in thisthrough its ally, Saudi Arabia. For a long time we were actuallyhelping them pick bombing sights even. We refueled their airplanes.We've sold them the weapons. We're working hand in glove with themin a war we have no business being part of.

BRZEZINSKI: Can you name one, two or three Pentagon programsthat you think could be eliminated?

WARREN: Hmm, that's interesting --

BRZEZINSKI: That's a good one. That's a tricker.

WARREN: Yes, it is. And I have to think about what -- what theprograms are. But let me -- can I describe it this way and tell youwhat the --

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The range is?

We have to stop the Pentagon from building the best possible20th century military and urge the Pentagon over to the 21st centurymilitary. And here's my example of that.

A lot of new tech. A lot of new cyber. The 21st century threatsand the 21st century responses are not places where a 20th centurymilitary has real strength. It's much more about conventionalweapons and large armies and so on and, you know, the ability toengage in lots of shooting wars around the world.

And the problem kind of coherent problem at the Pentagon isthat there's always somebody in the room to defend an existingprogram, no matter how old it is, no matter how much circumstanceshave changed. Somebody is at the head of that program. Somebodyhands out the dollars to the defense industry that supports thatprogram.

There's rarely somebody in the room for the next idea, for theplace we need to be. And yet to have an effective military, we'vegot to be on the front edge, not the back edge, of development.

So I can tell you where I'd spend a lot more money, it's only avery small part of the Pentagon budget, is on research, it's ondevelopment, it's on cyber. That's the place we've got to get thePentagon more focused in that direction.

BRZEZINSKI: Back to rapid-fire.

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: What has Donald Trump done that you think could beconsidered impeachable?

WARREN: Oh, come on now. No, but here's -- here's my rule onthis one.

BRZEZINSKI: OK.

WARREN: We're about to get the Mueller report. And --

BRZEZINSKI: Back up.

WARREN: We have a lot of other information. Let's wait untilwe've got the Mueller report, combine it with everything else we'veseen, then we'll know what to do.

BRZEZINSKI: So you agree with Nancy Pelosi's approach on this?

WARREN: I'm not sure where Nancy is when she says --

BRZEZINSKI: Well, she said he's not worth it at that point. Sodivisive.

WARREN: No. It's -- that's not the point. What I see is thatthe Mueller report is coming. Let's all take a look at the Muellerreport. And when the Mueller report comes, we'll know exactly whatto do.

BRZEZINSKI: What was wrong, if anything, with the statementsthat Representative Ilhan Omar made about Israel?

WARREN: You know, the way I see it is that we should -- we area great deliberative body in Congress. And it is important for us tobe able to debate issues, to do so respectfully. Any anti-Semitismor Islamophobia should be called out and condemned. But when shouldencourage our members --

BRZEZINSKI: So what she said were troupes and they were notworth --

WARREN: Well, when she'd doing that, then -- then that's aproblem. But the -- but here's -- here's the part I -- I really wantto make strongly. We've got to be a place that can have robustdiscussion. Not anti-Semitism, not Islamophobia, but robustdiscussion. And that's what we need to have.

BRZEZINSKI: What is it about Bernie Sanders that makes him sopopular with progressives?

WARREN: You know, because he fights for what he believes in.Bernie and I have been friends forever and ever.

BRZEZINSKI: Bernie's at the top of the list in these pollsright now --

WARREN: That's right.

BRZEZINSKI: Except for Biden, if he runs.

WARREN: That's right. But, you know, I've been friends withBernie from long, long before I ever ended up in politics. AndBernie's out there fighting for what he believes in. And I thinkthat -- that means a lot to people.

BRZEZINSKI: All right, two -- two more.

Is Mike Pence an honorable man?

WARREN: No.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. Would you like to expound upon that?

WARREN: Sure.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: Anyone who engages in the kind of homophobia andattacks on people who are different from himself is not an honorableperson. That's not -- that's not what honorable people do.

BRZEZINSKI: Should Bill Clinton have left office after havingan affair with a much younger staffer in the White House?

WARREN: I don't know. I can't go back and litigate the 1990s.That one -- that one is beyond me.

BRZEZINSKI: Did the 1990s get us here, though, to an extent?

WARREN: Of course it did. And -- but I don't have the timemachine to go back and change the '90s. All I can do is change thisworld going forward.

BRZEZINSKI: OK, Willie Geist, you can take over from here.

Willie.

WARREN: Go, Willie.

WILLIE GEIST, MSNBC CO-HOST: OK, senator, good to see you, asalways.

I want to ask you about your "Medium" post last week --

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Where you talked about the breakup of big tech. Theheadline is, it's time to break up Amazon, Google and FaceBook. Ithink your argument was a little more nuance perhaps in theheadline. Can you explain what you meant there?

WARREN: Sure. Let's use the example of Amazon. Amazon runs twokinds of businesses. One is it runs a platform. And that's the placewhere all the small businesses come and they trade and they -- buyerand sellers meet. And Amazon runs that platform, but also sucks outtons of information from every single transaction.

It then uses that information that nobody else is privy to, tolook out and say, oh, there's a profitable business. We think we'llgo into competition with them. And so it then puts out a product incompetition with the pillow sales guy and then moves the profitablebusiness back to page six and puts Amazon right at the front,Amazon's own business.

So, the way I see this, it's a little like baseball. We'll usea baseball analogy here. You can be the umpire, that's the platform,or you can have a team in the game, that's running these individualbusinesses that meet on the platform. But you don't get to do bothsimultaneously. So I think those ought to be broken apart.

GEIST: So another way to explain that too is let's take Apple.Obviously a very popular company. It has an app store.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: Do you believe that Apple should be allowed to sell itsown apps on its app store?

WARREN: So it needs to do one or the other. Either it runs thatplatform, the app store, or it's selling its own products on the appstore, but it doesn't do both of those simultaneously becausewhenever it does, it has this enormous competitive advantage thatwipes out all the other little businesses. In fact, did you know,Willie, that it's now referred to, this zone around folks like Appleand Google and Amazon, anyone that moves into the competition space,it's called the kill zone. And venture capitalists are investingabout 20 percent less than they used to on these start-up companiesbecause they know if they go into the kill zone, one of two thingswill happen. They'll either get gobbled up by the giant or they'llget wiped out by the giant, but they won't have a chance to grow anddevelop into what they might have been.

GEIST: So do you believe that Google, Amazon and FaceBook allare monopolies by your definition?

WARREN: Oh, I -- let's put it this way, they are huge. Theyhave market dominance and they behave like monopolists. And that's abig part of the reason they need to be broken apart.

Look at -- look at what happened with FaceBook. I don't knowabout you, but a lot of people are really uneasy about how FaceBookhandles their data.

GEIST: Yes.

WARREN: So, along comes What's App, right? And What's App says,I tell you what we'll do, we'll give a whole lot better protectionfor your privacy. And you watch a bunch of people move from FaceBookover to What's App. Now, that puts FaceBook in the position of doingone of two things, either they have to get better to meet thecompetition, that's what a good, robust market is all about, or, ifyou're already huge and dominate the field, just buy the competitionand take their data. FaceBook, of course, chose to do the latter.They shouldn't be allowed to do that. That is not furtheringcompetition.

You know, Willie, I believe in markets, but it's when marketshave rules, when markets have a cops on the beat to make sure thatthe giants aren't gobbling up everyone else and eliminatingcompetition. That's when markets work.

GEIST: So would you have worked to stop, in 2012, FaceBookpurchase of Instagram?

WARREN: Yes. And we can -- here's the thing. We can go back andstill do it. It's possible to go back under anti-trust laws and justsay, look, we let this merger go through. Often the mergers are onconditions, conditional that they're not going to do this or they'renot going to do that, but let the merger go through and look at itand say, it turns out it has anti-competitive effects. And if it hasanti-competitive effects, then we can go back and unwind these andbreak these pieces apart.

Understand, for anybody who still wants to go on FaceBook andcheck out their old college roommates or anyone who still wants togo to Amazon and price out 46 coffee makers and get the one that canbe delivered in 24 hours, or anybody who wants to go on Google andcheck out the capital of North Dakota, that will all still bepossible. The platforms will still be there. What will be differentis that the companies that are selling on those platforms will be ina real marketplace where they compete straight up based on price andservice and quality of goods, not having the platform owner able tocome in and have this enormous advantage to be able to scoop up allthe business and kill off the little businesses, the entrepreneursand the start-ups.

GEIST: You know, as you know well, senator, there's been thistension during the presidential campaign and it's come from commentsfrom members of your party who are not running for president in manycases about capitalism versus socialism. And I've been interested tohear you say time and again and one -- you said I'm a capitalist tothe bone. You were asked just on Sunday by John Heilemann on thecircus (ph) if you were a capitalist. You said, yes, I'm acapitalist.

WARREN: Yes.

GEIST: We know how you feel about new government programs,things you're going to add there.

How do you explain where you are on the question ofcapitalism/socialism and where do they marry each other?

WARREN: So, look, I believe in markets. That's where this wholepoint about tech is all about. I see the benefits that markets canproduce. I love the fact that there are a zillion people out theredeveloping new apps or starting new businesses or trying a secondone. I think that's fabulous. I think it's great that littlebusinesses are trying to get to be medium sized businesses andmedium sized businesses are trying to get to be large businesses.

But, understand this, markets without rules are theft. Andthere's got to be rules and there's got to be a cop on the beat.

You and I go a long way back. You remember back before thecrash that what had happened basically was the financial giants hadfigured out they could make buckets of money by cheating theircustomers, mortgages, credit cards. And, sure enough, that's whatthey were doing. The cops on the beat, the regulators, just lookedthe other way, paid no attention. And the consequence was, big banksmade a lot of money. They broke the backs of millions of familiesand ultimately crashed our economy. That's why we needed rules.

So, I came in with the idea of the Consumer FinancialProtection Bureau. We got that bureau in place. And now you begin tosee a much more level playing field. When there's a cop on the beat,those markets start to work again and banks, in that case, areforced to develop their profit models, not on cheating people, buton actually offering a better product.

Now, Wells Fargo proves they're still willing to get out thereand try to cheat people, but at least we had some cops who caughtthem and have hauled them in and are trying to make changes in thecompany. That's what it takes. Markets have a lot to produce, butonly if they have rules and if they have a cop that's enforcingthose rules.

GEIST: So, senator, despite its flaws, some of which you'velaid out there, do you believe capitalism over the course of historyhas been a force for good?

WARREN: So I -- yes, I do. I think it also, when -- when itdoesn't work, it's been a force for bad, but that's been true ofevery form of government that we can identify, that we've gotten itright sometimes and gotten it wrong sometimes. When you let marketswork with rules and with people on the beat to enforce those rules,we can produce a lot of wealth in this country. That's what we'vedone for a very long time. We have to recognize there are areaswhere markets don't work.

Health care, for example. Somebody having a heart attack is notsomebody who's going to shop around to six different emergency roomsand say, which one is going to give me the best price?

Their -- education. Public education. That's not a place wherea market works.

But there are places where markets do work. Coffee makers, petpillows. I'm in. We need robust markets for those. That's how weproduce.

By the way, that's how we ended up producing the Amazon's andGoogles and FaceBooks of the world is the fact that markets couldgrow these incredible, incredible businesses.

BRZEZINSKI: So let me close by asking you, a lot of people seemto think the Democrats are most interested in having someone who canbeat Trump and Trump is a street fighter and he plays by unfairrules. I feel like, just my opinion here, that Hillary Clinton was abit boxed in on the debate stage, especially on issues pertaining tomisogyny and sexism. I just feel like it's -- it was an area whereshe was extremely uncomfortable.

How would nominee Elizabeth Warren handle President Trump onthe debate stage? Would you call him out on his misogyny? Would youcall him out on his treatment of women? Would you call him out onhis record? And how would you fight back when he calls you names?

WARREN: So I'm not afraid --

BRZEZINSKI: I want to know what this looks like.

WARREN: OK. Let's start with, I am not afraid of anyone, andparticularly not Donald Trump. People have told me, for most of mylife, what's too hard to get done. And my response has always beento fight back. The consumer agency, right? So, after the big crash--

BRZEZINSKI: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau created byElizabeth Warren.

WARREN: That's right. I -- I came in and said, we need thisagency.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: You know what people in Washington said to me? Theysaid two things. The first one is, that's a great idea. That wouldactually change the world.

BRZEZINSKI: Yes.

WARREN: The second is, don't do it. Don't even try because it'stoo hard. You won't be able to get it done. You'll be up against thebanks. They'll spend millions of dollars a day lobbying against thisthing. And you know what my response was, I just got in the fight.And I got in the fight and I stayed in the fight. And today theconsumer agency is the law of the land.

BRZEZINSKI: Are you afraid to get into his fight and to getinto his face when one needs to?

WARREN: Not even a little bit.

BRZEZINSKI: OK. All right, you've got it go, I know. You've gota train to catch.

Senator Elizabeth Warren, thank you very much. It's great tohave you. Come back anytime.

WARREN: Oh, it's so good to be here.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XD2-GVW1-DY2S-N4BG-00000-00Sen. Elizabeth Warren Talks With Democratic Voters About Their Concerns2019-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisAll Things Considered11:00 AM ESTScott DetrowElizabeth WarrenHugh ThompsonMarySen. Elizabeth Warren Talks With Democratic Voters About Their Concerns

MARY LOUISE KELLY: How can Massachusetts Senator Elizabeth Warren win a general election? That is the question more and more Democrats are asking as she rises in the polls. Plenty of voters are skeptical, as NPR's Scott Detrow reports from New Hampshire.

SCOTT DETROW: Elizabeth Warren works a room like she performs at a big rally - with a lot of energy. At a Concord, N.H., Mexican restaurant this week, she was doling out birthday greetings...

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED CHILD: Today's my birthday.

ELIZABETH WARREN: No.

SCOTT DETROW: ...Pitching people on single-payer health care and her student debt plan...

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: Yeah, I really depend on...

ELIZABETH WARREN: One more reason to...

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: Yeah.

ELIZABETH WARREN: You bet. And besides that, how about we do things like universal child care and tuition-free college?

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #1: That would be unreal.

SCOTT DETROW: ...And just spouting out her campaign slogan as she strode past people who were mid-burrito-bite.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: Hi.

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: How you doing?

ELIZABETH WARREN: It's nice to see you.

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: Nice to meet you.

ELIZABETH WARREN: Very nice to meet you, too. We have got to stay in this fight.

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON #2: I agree.

SCOTT DETROW: This is Warren's campaign - unapologetically aggressive in tone and in policy.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: We need a president with the courage to enforce the anti-trust laws, break up big tech, big ag, big pharma. It's time.

SCOTT DETROW: At a town hall in Laconia, her 150th of the campaign, Warren ticked through all of her campaign goals - all that regulation, plus a wealth tax that would fund education spending, student debt relief, single-payer health care and more.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: OK, so I could, like, do these all day long.

SCOTT DETROW: But the more Warren rises in the polls in key early states like New Hampshire, the more supporters are envisioning what she would be like as the party's nominee. And that's leading to nervous questions, like this from Hugh Thompson (ph).

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

HUGH THOMPSON: I like everything you say.

ELIZABETH WARREN: Oh, good. Let's stop there.

HUGH THOMPSON: OK.

ELIZABETH WARREN: (Laughter).

HUGH THOMPSON: But...

ELIZABETH WARREN: Uh-huh.

HUGH THOMPSON: ...We also need to get you elected.

SCOTT DETROW: Thompson's worry - a lot of Democrats may love Warren's progressive agenda, but how will independents and Republicans react? Warren's response is twofold. First, she argues a Democratic candidate needs to get Democrats excited.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: I think you have to give people a reason to show up. I think you have to give people some hope and a reason to get in the fight.

SCOTT DETROW: And she says her populism is something that could break through party lines.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: The day as president - oh, I like saying that - as president that I get to sign into law the cancellation of student debt for 43 million Americans, that's a day where Democrats do well, Republicans do well, independents do well.

SCOTT DETROW: In Laconia, Warren got another question about a whole different type of Democratic angst - confronting President Trump.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

MARY: When he calls you Pocahontas, I'm sure you have an answer for him. I would like to know how you're going to come at him. Are you going to go after him? What are you going to do?

SCOTT DETROW: Warren says she'll stand up for herself but will try to avoid getting into an insult cycle.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: My goal is to tap into all of the Americans who are just getting tired of the Donald Trump show. It's just getting old, and it's getting boring. And that's what's starting to happen.

SCOTT DETROW: Questioner's name is Mary, but she didn't want to give her last name.

MARY: I didn't like her answer because Hillary took the high road, and it got her nowhere. And...

SCOTT DETROW: Mary says she's planning on voting for Tom Steyer, but Warren wasn't ready to give up on her vote. Just as Mary finished talking to NPR, Warren popped in hoping to make a connection with a selfie.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)

ELIZABETH WARREN: Want a picture?

MARY: Oh, sure. I don't have a camera, so don't worry about it.

ELIZABETH WARREN: Oh, OK.

MARY: No, I don't need a picture.

ELIZABETH WARREN: Thank you, Mary.

MARY: Thank you. Good luck to you.

SCOTT DETROW: Scott Detrow, NPR News, Laconia, N.H.

(SOUNDBITE OF MASHROU' LEILA'S "3 MINUTES")
