Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJB-3FT1-JB20-G150-00000-00Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) Interviewed About The Social Media Summit; Trump Expected To Announce Decision On Census Today; President Trump Hosting Social Media Summit Today At the White House; Goldilocks State Of Affairs; Big Business Of CBD; Cashing In On Cannabis2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, Marsha Blackburn, Krishna Memani, Robert HormatsNEWSFinancial071103cb.231Sen. Marsha Blackburn (R-TN) Interviewed About The Social Media Summit; Trump Expected To Announce Decision On Census Today; President Trump Hosting Social Media Summit Today At the White House; Goldilocks State Of Affairs; Big Business Of CBD; Cashing In On CannabisMaria Bartiromo, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, Blake Burman, Cheryl Casone, Lauren Simonetti, Jonathan Novack, Stuart Varney, Ashley Webster

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: -- before 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell driving markets this morning. Take a look. Futures pointing to a gain at the start of trading after Powell signaled a rate cut maybe on the way. The Dow futures up 89 points, S&P up six, NASDAQ up 19 points right now. The NASDAQ hitting new intraday high ad closed at a new high.

In fact, all the indices hit all new intraday high but it's the only NASDAQ to finish there. The S&P 500 crossed 3,000 yesterday, the NASDAQ as I said at a record-high this morning t 82.02. European indices pretty much flat today. Take a look, FT-100 down two points, CAC quarante up six, DAX index in Germany lower by 22. Minutes from last month's ECB meeting just released saying that the members agreed on the need be ready to provide more stimulus to Eurozone in an environment of heightened uncertainty from the European Central Bank.

Not a lot of movement in markets, post that. That's basically what we heard from Mario Draghi last week as well. Asian markets were higher this -- overnight, take a look, pretty much higher across the board, a fractional move in China. Escalating tensions with Iran meanwhile. Iranian gunboats tried to seize a British oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz but the attempt warded after a British warship intervened.

Delta raised guidance for the year, it's also raising its dividend. The airline reporting a profit beat on higher travel demand and raising its profit guidance. the stock is up better than two percent as the company also takes dividends up. The world's highest-paid entertainers, Kanye West coming in at number three on the Forbes list. Find out you who is earning top dollar. And Steve Forbes is here with us this morning.

All of that coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, assistant editorial page editor for the Wall Street Journal, James Freeman, and Forbes Media chairman, former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes. Great to see everybody this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be here. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Really good show. A lot of interesting interviews as well, talking about the issues of the day. What's most important to you?

FORBES: Right now is the Federal Reserve. And yes, they're all focusing on interest rates but I'm concerned about getting a non-Fed person on that board. Judy Shelton, they already did a bank shot yesterday with Powell going against the gold standard as a way of hitting her and there is going to be a big battle ahead but we got to get diversity on the Federal Reserve board.

BARTIROMO: You want a dissident there?

FORBES: Yes. They need to ask hard questions. The idea of the prosperity causing inflation, that's got to be attacked.

BARTIROMO: Yes. By the way, that's exactly what Charles Plosser just said. Former president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve was here.

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And said, what's wrong with prosperity and no inflation?

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes. Shelton is a rock star and, you know, people have talked about President Trump with the -- with the kooky tweets and the rest of it might have trouble attracting talented people to his administration. Here's another outstanding potential hire assuming Senate confirmation. She called the collapse of the Soviet Union, that's one of the -- one of the great calls in history and a lot of smart writing in research since then.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: And also, speaking of hires, Alex Acosta, the labor secretary, only thing you need to point out is he's essentially -- his main job is to promote how awesome the job market is and how great job growth is. Wages growing at the fastest pace of 10 years. Is he a distraction? Can he do that job going forward? Who do we see on jobs day? Larry Kudlow, we see Kevin Hassett all the time, the economic adviser.

Not really Alex Acosta. So why is he there and is he a distraction in the weeks and months to come if he stays around? I just raised that issue but --

BARTIROMO: No --

MCDOWELL: Again, so you're there to promote labor policy, the great -- the great job market, and it's all of this too much?

BARTIROMO: We're watching that for sure.

FORBES: The labor department has been doing some good things removing barriers to hiring that don't get much publicity part of this deregulation push.

BARTIROMO: And skills training.

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Which is another important element there. We're talking about all of that this morning. And our top story right now President Trump is posting a social media summit at the White House later day. Blake Burman live at the White House right now with the very latest. Blake, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Maria, good morning to you as well. We got our very first surprise of the day over here at the White House. At 6:39 this morning it came via Twitter as President Trump announced that after that social media summit here at the White House there will also be a news conference regarding the issue of the citizenship question on the census.

Let's sort of break this down one by one. The President later went on to Twitter as well to talk about the social media summit and he said the following, he wrote, "A big subject today at the White House. Social media summit will be a tremendous dishonesty bias discrimination and suppression practice by certain companies. We will not let them get away with it much longer." As you can see at the end of the tweet there, he also followed up with several others.

He then went on to rail against what calls the fake news media. Now, after that summit, the expectation is the President will announce his course of action, regarding the census and the citizenship question. Earlier this week, the President talked up the possibility of an executive order as the Supreme Court has recently kicked the matter back to a lower court, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We'll see what happens. We can also add an addition on so we can start the printing now and maybe do an addendum after we get a positive decision. So we're working on a lot of things, including an executive order.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Now, if the President goes the route of an executive order, Maria, you can certainly expect the lawsuits to follow after that, because the current dynamic right now is this. This is still a matter that is being handled in the court system and as it relates to the census, the census is already being printed. The President clearly doesn't like that dynamic or where everything stands right now and he is potentially trying to change all of that. We'll see how he tries to go about it later today. Maria?

BARTIROMO: All right, Blake. Thanks so much. Blake Burman with the latest there. Joining me right now is Tennessee Senator, member of the Judiciary and Armed Services Committee is Marsha Blackburn. Senator, it's good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining me.

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN): Good to see you. Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: So we're talking about this White House summit, you're urging big tech to protect young children. What do you want to see at a big technology?

BLACKBURN: What I would like to see out of big tech is some responsibility and accountability. And Maria, they go in and subjectively manipulate their algorithms and then opens the doors that it ought not to children like the Snapchat letter that I sent this week. Deals with the way pornography is made public on their site. And this is made available, the ratings are wrong on these apps, children are seeing this, they need to adjust those ratings.

And also, parents need to be aware. You need to give parents the tools to block this. These videos that are deleted, this becomes a child predator's dream for contacting these children and there are several cases where pedophiles have used Snapchat to contact and to coerce these children.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That's unbelievable.

BLACKBURN: It is unbelievable.

BARTIROMO: It feels like this is one issue big tech hits at both corners and both sides of the aisle, you've got people like Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz both saying that they want to break these companies up. Do you want to see breakups of some of these large companies that are today, as you know, more powerful than we've ever known?

BLACKBURN: Well, I think where we start is with privacy issue. And yesterday, Chris Hughes, who was the co-founder of Facebook was in my office, and we had a very productive discussion about how you deal with privacy and giving consumers the toolbox to protect this -- I term (ph, their virtual hue themselves online. So you start with privacy and data security, you look at how the social media giants are prioritizing their content over content that should be readily available online.

And I'm going to have a meeting later today with the CEO of Yelp concerning this, issue because they're conducting -- Google prioritizes their content, so that determines what people see, what they have access to. We're also going to look at censorship and antitrust and say do these companies need to reposition themselves? But I think first, you look at the privacy issue and you determine how that forces the media companies to adjust their business model.

Right now, they are -- they built their business model on a no holds barred, they do not have to inform you that they are taking your data, that they are mining your data, that they are positioning your data to be sold to the highest bidder who is going to market back to you or is going to go through and sift your data and then determine what they want to push forward to you in the method of videos or articles.

It's like with YouTube. You look at one video then they fill a stream with similar videos.

BARTIROMO: So, real quick, I want to move to the border but let me -- let me end this here on this, because when I spoke with the President a couple of weeks ago, he said, look, we might need legislation which will spur competition. Do you want to see regulation for these companies?

BLACKBURN: The BROWSER Act is legislation that deals with the privacy issue that I introduced in the House. I have reintroduced that in the Senate and we are working to move that forward to get those guardrails in place. And to do first, like touch --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: -- like touch, but to put those parameters in place.

BARTIROMO: Understood. Let me move to the crisis at the border, Senator, because Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agents are reportedly preparing to conduct raids beginning Sunday to arrest thousands of illegal immigrants across the country. The move coming weeks after President Trump said that the operation was first being delayed. You're headed to the southern border with Vice President Mike Pence tomorrow.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What are you expecting? And do you think we're ever going to get our arms around these loopholes that are encouraging so many illegals, migrants to flood the border?

BLACKBURN: The thing is we have to get our hands around the loopholes, and we have to plug these loopholes if you will, and make certain that those who are coming to our country come here legally. The border patrol -- I was down there, a couple of months ago and they are in desperate need of some help, and my hope is that our Democrat colleagues will begin to work with us to give the border patrol the three things they continue to say they need, they have been saying this for 20 years. Give them a barrier, give them appropriate technology, give them more officers, agents, and judges to deal with this issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But let's be honest, they don't want the President to have a victory. They -- I mean some people on Democrats side hate him so much that they're just going to try to make a point and not do anything about this issue. Do you really see anything getting done?

BLACKBURN: Maria -- yes. I've got to tell you, they need to get over their pettiness and they need to put this nation and our sovereignty and the protection of the American people first.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I understand.

BLACKBURN: They need to -- they need to stop this human trafficking, sex trafficking, drug trafficking that is taking place on our border. Every town is a border down, every state is a border state, because of the drugs and the human trafficking coming through. They need to get over themselves.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Because all these people --

BLACKBURN: They lost that election, they need to work for the good of the American people.

BARTIROMO: All these people are coming to the border in facing these situations where before they even get to the border, they've got to deal with the drug lords, so there is that.

BLACKBURN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: And then, you know, they don't want to do anything there, but there's also an issue on trade. So let me ask you about USMCA.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What is the likelihood that the -- that the bill comes to the floor for a vote in the fall?

BLACKBURN: The votes are there. If Pelosi were to put it on the floor today, it would pass.

BARTIROMO: So why isn't she?

BLACKBURN: I think that there -- again, you're looking at people that say "Well do we want to give Donald Trump a victory?" Give the American people a victory. The unions are for this, the farmers are for this, come on, guys. Put it on the floor --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: All right. So you don't know -- you don't know is the answer if she's going to bring it to the floor by fall. Is that what you were saying?

BLACKBURN: She should bring it to the fall -- to the floor next week.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly. OK. Let me ask about China. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is going to be meeting with members to discuss USMCA. I spoke with Vice President Mike Pence's chief of staff Marc Short on the program yesterday. He is the one who said it's probably going to come to the floor in the fall. What's plan B if she doesn't bring it to the floor? I mean, could that happen that she actually doesn't bring it to the floor?

BLACKBURN: I think she will see what happened to the border funding bill before last where you will see the moderates in her caucus say, "Come on, Nancy, let's get with it. Let's get this job done." And when you have the unions and so many of the trade groups all saying "USMCA, let's push it forward," she needs to say -- she and Steny need to say, let's put it on the floor and call the vote, let chips fall where they may.

Let Nancy and Steny declare victory by being able to move something forward. We need to get this thing done. When it comes to China, we're going to continue to encourage holding that line against Huawei. China will steal our intellectual property, they will embed chips and builds Huawei as a spy network in that equipment and consumer products. We need to make certain that we deal with that issue and not give them an edge. We know what they're up to.

BARTIROMO: Well, you certainly have been keeping -- and the President has been keeping his boot on the neck of the Chinese on this issue for sure. Senator, it's good to see you as always. Thanks so much.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Marsha Blackburn joining us there. Coming up. We are awaiting June consumer prices. The CPI is due out in 15 minutes time. The economists are expecting it to be unchanged. Zero percent. We are bringing you the number. We'll see if markets get impacted there. It came up yesterday in the Fed's talk. Then fame and fortune. Forbes' coveted list of highest-paid celebrities is out. The star topping, Kylie Jenner is next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Shares of Delta airlines rallying the premarket this morning. A lot of news there. Cheryl Casone on it right now.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: A lot to unpack, Maria, with these earnings. These are the second-quarter results. They beat expectations both the top and the bottom line. They had strong demand for travel, especially for premium class tickets. They also raised a profit guidance for the year. They did raise their quarterly dividend as well. Take a look at the stock of the premarket, it's up two percent.

Now, remember, they don't fly any Boeing 737 Max jets. Those, of course, have been grounded following two deadly crashes. Now to a different earnings story this morning. This is Bed Bath & Beyond. Adjusted profit coming in better than expected but revenue fell from a year ago and it actually missed the forecast the street had on them. The stock is down more than 40 percent from a year ago. And as you can see, it's trading down almost four percent in the premarket right now. Two stocks a to watch for you today.

Also, Lockheed Martin is going to be staying in Pennsylvania. The defense giant keeping a helicopter plant open there after President Trump called for it. The President tweeted after the news was released "I was just informed by Marillyn Hewson, CEO of Lockheed Martin of decision to keep -- this of course, the helicopter plant in Coatesville, Pennsylvania open and humming. We are very proud of Pennsylvania and the people who work here -- work there. Thank you to Lockheed Martin. One of the USA's great companies.

And she may be worth a billion dollars but Kylie Jenner is not the world's highest-paid celebrity. This is all for Steve Forbes I think. Shaking it up at the top of the Forbes list, Taylor Swift earned $185 million over the past year. OK. Jenner has now slouched, she came in number two, $170 million. And there are your top five guys of the Forbes list, I'll say that again, musician Kanye West, soccer star Lionel Messi, and musician Ed Sheeran. Interesting names there on that list, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Really are. The Forbes list, something that we look forward to. It's great list. I love the list that Forbes puts together, Steve, because it really gives you a sense of --the equitable amount of wealth in this country.

FORBES: Wealth and entrepreneurship. We got criticized of putting Kylie Jenner on our cover a year ago. So, saying she's a self-made -- come a self-made billionaire.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: And by golly she is doing it.

BARTIROMO: Sure is. All right. Quick break. And then we are waiting the CPI, the consumer price index due out in 10 minutes time. Economists expected to be unchanged. We'll bring you the numbers, see if it impacts markets, next. Then the Fed in focus. Futures higher this morning rallying after the testimony yesterday hopes that we're going to see a rate cut in a couple of weeks. What you need to know ahead of the open this morning. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets hit record-highs yesterday after Fed Chairman Powell's testimony before Congress. He indicated that a rate cut could be coming later this month. We are looking at more gains today. Dow Industrials up 113 points. S&P up seven and the NASDAQ up 23. This right here, this is the high of the morning. Joining us right now is Invesco Vice Chairman of Investments, Krishna Memani. Great to see you, Krishna.

KRISHNA MEMANI, VICE CHAIRMAN OF INVESTMENTS, INVESCO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: You said we are looking at further gains, your call is five more years of a bull market.

MEMANI: Yes. So five more years of growth and therefore five more years of a bull market. The key point that I would like to make is the lack of inflationary pressures in the global economy provides the central bankers the flexibility that they need to manufacture economic outcomes. They're not being forced into a corner, much the way the Fed did in 2018 if things get hot and heavy and they start tightening at the -- at the right moment they have the flexibility to pivot. That's what they did and that's why it's probably going lower for a while.

BARTIROMO: How come they don't act like that, Steve? I mean, this is -- it's like we have been having this debate all morning about why the Fed doesn't believe that prosperity is possible without inflation never do anything about it.

FORBES: No. You don't feel that if the economy starts to do well they're going to talk about overheating, your incomes are going up, so you're sweating at night, you got to cool it off.

MEMANI: Instinctively, they are still working off of all data sets. You know, in their mind they have been -- unemployment rate gets to a certain level, it will reach -- lead to inflationary pressures. Unfortunately, that's not how things have worked out in the cycle -- for most of the cycle. So I think, they don't like the current environment but I think they are adjusting to the --

FORBES: Actually they're a lagging indicator.

MEMANI: Oh, absolutely. Intellectually, they still believe in the Phillips curve although Phillips curve hasn't materialized so far in this cycle and it's unlikely to because the global economy is very different. Globalization, demographic pressures technology keeps inflation under control, that allows overall rates to be far more stimulative --

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: What about political travels in New York spilling over? Do you see any threats there?

MEMANI: Well -- so, you know, if you go back in the cycle 2011, 2012, we had far more political trouble in euro but we were on the verge of -- Europe breaking up the common currency going down and didn't materialize. And I think what we need to do is make sure that at the right pivot points, somebody comes up like Draghi in 2011 to support the economy. So, I think as long as we don't make -- we don't make mistakes, we don't have our own goals, the global growth can continue for a bit.

FORBES: And the markets down by.

MEMANI: So -- I think, the markets are going to be driven ultimately by globe economy, and global economy overall continues to do well, the emerging markets --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: All right.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thank so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday. We have breaking news, another important read -- June consumer prices due out in a couple of seconds. Economists are expecting it to be unchanged month-over-month, but up 1.6 percent year-over-year. The Consumer Price Index is basically measuring prices at the cash register. Are we actually seeing consumers pay more for goods when they are at the register? Month-over-month, it's up one-tenth of a percent, the numbers are out, one-tenth of a percent is certainly higher than we were expecting. Lauren Simonetti with more on the CPI right now. Lauren.

LAUREN SIMONETTI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We are getting the numbers for the Consumer Price Index, Maria. And market reaction not liking this. A little bit hotter for the month-over-month number for the month of June, a rise of one-tenth of one percent. The market was expecting a flat reading. Year-over-year in line, 1.6 percent. Just looking through the numbers a little bit more right now, Maria, give me one quick second. If I can do the -- I can't get the breakdown at this moment, but I will check back and --

BARTIROMO: The year-over-year -- Lauren, the year-over-year --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- at 1.6 percent is pretty much in line with expectations, and obviously --

SIMONETTI: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- we want to look at this number, because the Federal Reserve continues to say that the inflationary story is below its two percent target, and we're seeing that again at 1.6 percent year-over-year.

SIMONETTI: Let me get to the core number here, Maria, if I can. This is ex-food and energy, which are more volatile. We were expecting 0.2 percent. This came in hotter at 0.3 percent, so a little bit more inflation in this June CPI read. The year-over-year core read also a tad bit higher at 2.1 percent versus the two percent expectation. So that is some more information from this report.

BARTIROMO: All right. We are not seeing a major move, but certainly markets have cooled off from the highs of the morning.

SIMONETTI: Well, right --

BARTIROMO: Dow Industrials --

SIMONETTI: Right --

BARTIROMO: Yes, go ahead.

SIMONETTI: -- before this, the Dow was up 111 seconds before, now it's up 69. The S&P was up seven moments before this report, seconds before. Now it's up two points. So, we do have -- we're looking at a higher open, but nonetheless, we have come off those highs. How much, if at all, does this change the leeway the Fed has to do --

BARTIROMO: Yes. It's --

SIMONETTI: -- to do a cut in a couple weeks.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We are definitely seeing the markets come off of the highs. Lauren, thank you.

SIMONETTI: Yes. Sure.

BARTIROMO: We'll keep reading these numbers and see what they tell us. And joining us right now is Former Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment, Robert Hormats joining the conversation right now. Bob, it's good to see you.

ROBERT HORMATS, FORMER UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE FOR ECONOMIC GROWTH, ENERGY, AND THE ENVIRONMENT: Great to be with you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: When you look at a CPI number like this, you say what? What does this tell us?

HORMATS: A -- first of all, I don't pay a lot of attention to month-to- month number, second, if there is anything moving it up a little bit, it's -- we've had a decline in healthcare cost for a while. Maybe they're beginning to trickle up a little bit. Housing may be going up a tiny bit. But in general, with a very competitive global environment, we don't have to worry too much about a deflation, and a slight increase in inflation is not really troublesome.

I do think if we get into a real trade war and prices go up because of higher tariffs, that will be inflationary, but it's also, in a way, going to slow growth, because it's an effective tax, so that may be looked at one way as inflation, another way as actually growth slowing.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point.

FREEMAN: I'm wondering about the case for a rate cut, Fed Chairman Jay Powell talking about uncertainties just fighting it. You hear the same kind of similar message from Europe, if President Trump tweets tomorrow morning that Xi of China is a great guy and this beautiful country is going to lower tariffs, does that mean they raise rates?

HORMATS: Well, I must say I'm very uncomfortable with the point that he links this in rhetoric, perhaps not so much in decision-making, but certainly on what he said to the uncertainty over a trade war, because as you correctly point out, a lot of what's going on in trade is short-term, some of it is negotiating tactics.

FREEMAN: Yes.

HORMATS: We don't know what's going to happen three or four months from now. There is uncertainty, but if there's a deal with China and they're all eliminated, does that cause the Fed to change its mind? If it gets worse, does that cause the Fed to get even more concerned and lower rates further? But to trigger trade policy -- you have trade policy in effect, trigger Fed policy to me is not a comfortable thing because it's so volatile, so unpredictable, and it can change week-to-week, month-to-month, day-to-day, hour-to-hour. The Fed shouldn't focus on those kind of short- term things. If it's a long-term trade war, that's a different matter. But a lot of this is tactical.

FORBES: On the trade front, do you have worries about autos that -- that's going to be worrisome?

HORMATS: Yes, I think it would be a terrible thing if we start -- first of all, the national security argument for restricting, putting tariffs on autos, to me, just doesn't make much sense. Second, it'll have a major impact on a lot of consumers, and third, what we should be doing is getting allies among our major trading partners, the Japanese, the Europeans and working with them to deal with global trade issues. If we take very tough action against them --

FORBES: Do you think -- do you think tariffs are going to get caught up in the dispute with France over them putting taxes on our --

HORMATS: Well, I think there will be some dispute and some retaliatory measures by the United States. I would hope that we don't use a sledgehammer, and auto tariffs would certainly be a sledgehammer. Very disruptive, not just to the American consumer, but to the global trading system. And at a time when you need allies, if you're going to try to get our rules of the global order accepted by the rest of the world, you don't want to be making enemies among the countries that have the closest sets of views on the market to those that we have.

BARTIROMO: What do you -- what do you think of the revenue that this country is taking in? I mean the president will always push back when you -- when you criticize tariffs and say, "I've taken in a hundred billion dollars, I'm going to be taking in a hundred billion dollars in revenue as a result of these tariffs on China."

HORMATS: Oh, I think this argument has gotten so confusing. Americans pay the tariffs. Now the Chinese may, in some cases, lower the price of certain goods to be able to clear the American market, but the tariff is a tax. Who pays the tax? Americans pay the tax. Second, the amount of money paid by almost all accounts has been something in the order of 20, $20-plus billion, it's not a hundred billion dollars.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HORMATS: So, I think we have to look at it --

BARTIROMO: I think he's talking about the final -- the final $325 billion (INAUDIBLE)

HORMATS: Well, if we were to do --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: If we were to do it. And so far, it's around $20 billion. If we were to do that, Americans would still pay the tariffs.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: The problem is then you would have a slowing of growth, prices would go up, growth would probably slow because it is a tax. Other countries would and there is some argument here that we wouldn't pay the whole burden, we would pay the taxes but prices that other countries charge us, the exporters of China for instance, charge us would probably go down in order to clear the market at a lower price, but the tariff payments by Americans, the final price may not be as high as the tariffs, because the Chinese may, in effect, cut the sales tax.

BARTIROMO: I think there's full agreements on this.

MCDOWELL: Well -- but let me phrase it. Let me position it like this. U.S. corporations ship these jobs overseas. They used to be good-paying jobs with a safety net here in the United States, and they essentially ship them overseas for what was a boost to their profits. Politicians sat back and went, "That's fine with us," until there was an uproar and President Trump gets elected.

We now have what is essentially, with these tariffs on Chinese imports, a - -it's not a border tax, but it's a value-added tax on goods coming into this country, but at the same time, they cut corporate taxes, so there is that offset. So, it's actually almost -- if you look at it from 35,000 feet, a change in the way that we tax, we incentivize saving, we -- basically tax spending, if you will, discourage spending in the U.S., and we have the offset of the corporate tax cut here in the United States. It's kind of brilliant if you look at it from an economic perspective.

HORMATS: Well, the corporate tax cut, I totally agree. That's a very positive thing. What I think is part of the equation here, particularly if this is a longer term trade war, is that the notion of supply chains is going to be changed. There are companies that are moving their source of supply out of China into Vietnam, into Mexico, and some of it back in the United States. So, we're getting some benefit there, but I would -- I would -- I wouldn't necessarily equate the two and it's sort of hard to figure out what the overall impact on the American economy is.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Good op-ed in The Journal this morning about that.

MCDOWELL: Right. I was going to --

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE) Vietnam loves Donald Trump.

MCDOWELL: They --

HORMATS: Yes, they do. But it's very hard to -- you can't use light switch tactics to change your supply chain overnight. These supply chains have been developed in China over decades, literally. Chinese have great infrastructure, Vietnam does not, Chinese have a lot more trained workers, Vietnam does not. They have a lot of STEM workers in China that -- one reason the U.S. wants to invest there, and do research there, is that there are a lot of talented Chinese. I go there all the time and I see them, so it's not so easy to change supply chains in a -- in an instant. It take -- it's costly.

MCDOWELL: But The Journal --

FREEMAN: What about --

MCDOWELL: But The Journal cites this, Chinese goods exports to U.S. fell more than 12 percent year-over-year --

HORMATS: Oh, that's true.

MCDOWELL: -- from January through May. Vietnam saw a 36 -- more than 36 percent increase over the same period of time.

HORMATS: Those are mostly in very labor-intensive products.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

HORMATS: That's certainly true.

FREEMAN: But it is -- it is leverage on China. Who knows if they will want to stop stealing intellectual property, make a deal, but it does suggest if we want to look somewhere other than the Fed for growth, that if this China negotiation is going to continue, the president ought to be lowering barriers in our trade with other countries, right?

HORMATS: Yes. For two reasons, one, in effect of your lower barriers, your lower taxes in effect. And second, it'll boost growth in these countries and they're our major trading partners, they'll buy more from us. So it would be a stimulus --

BARTIROMO: And they realize the uncertainty because the president has said over and over again that the Europeans treat us worse than China does, that India treats us badly, that there are -- actually, he even said in an interview a week and a half ago when he joined this program, Vietnam is another one. So, you've got all of these questions about who's next in terms of the target of the president.

FORBES: And Japan, the third largest economy in the world. What -- what's the trade situation there?

HORMATS: Yes. So I mean the -- you have to pick your spots when you go into these kinds of things. You can't have this against everyone, and it seems to me you want to be work with the Japanese, you want to be working with the Europeans, you want be working with the Canadians, and Mexicans. NAFTA --

FORBES: Geopolitically with the Indians.

HORMATS: Geo -- and geo -- and definitely geopolitical with the Indians.

BARTIROMO: Do you think USMCA passes? Do you think she brings it to the floor for a vote, USMCA?

HORMATS: Probably not in august, but I do think they're working very hard. And in fact, on a bipartisan basis, which is one of the few things that's happening, Washington bipartisan basis, and they're dealing with issues like labor, enforcement, and environmental issues, and I do think that she'll bring it to a vote. Perhaps they don't want to -- we only have nine days in August, but after the August recess, I would guess they would -- they -- both sides -- both sides would benefit.

And I'd just like to add one more point on the China thing, we're paying a lot of attention, and understandably so to all the issues with China because we see China as a major competitor now and particularly in technology and in the future.

BARTIROMO: And a national security risk.

HORMATS: Yes. And the technology has both economic and national security implications. What we're missing in this debate, and perhaps distracted from it, is that we need to do a lot more to strengthen our own competitiveness at home. If you want to be competing with this rise in China, you need -- you can't be cutting money from the National Science Foundation, the national labs. You need to take advantage of talented foreigner workers, you need a competitive excessive infrastructure environment. You need to support STEM education.

So, what we ought to be doing, A, is competing with China and trying to get the rules agreed on the basis of much more market orientation for the global trading rules, and the bilateral trading rules, but we also can't be diverted from the fact that we need to do a lot more at home --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: -- as we did during the space race to strengthen our capabilities.

FORBES: And the taxes, flat tax, wouldn't that help?

HORMATS: Well, lower -- Steve. Steve.

BARTIROMO: (INAUDIBLE)

HORMATS: That'll be (INAUDIBLE) but let's -- we got to take an inventory, what do we need to do at home to strengthen --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

HORMATS: -- our competitive capabilities as we did during the space race?

BARTIROMO: Yes. All good points. Bob, it's great to have your insights. You got to come back more often.

HORMATS: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. Bob Hormats joining us there.

HORMATS: It's a pleasure. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, the markets record run, futures moving higher this morning, all three major indices hitting intraday highs yesterday. Stuart Varney weighs in on that ahead of the opening bell, which is just in about 45 minutes. And then cashing in on cannabis, we're going to take you live to one of the world's largest marijuana companies for closer look at the drug. What is happening here? But first, check out The Tennis Channel.

JONATHAN NOVACK, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel Court Report. For FOX Business, I'm Jonathan Novack. The Men's Semifinals are now set at Wimbledon and it's giving us the matchup we've all been dreaming of, Federer versus Nadal. Roger Federer defeated Kei Nishikori in the quarterfinals and made history in the process. He became the first man to win a hundred marches at a single major and broke Jimmy Connors' record for most grass court victories in the Open Era.

Federer will now face his greatest rival, Rafael Nadal, who won his quarterfinal over Sam Querrey. That will set up the first match between Federer and Nadal at Wimbledon since their epic 2008 final, what many people call the greatest tennis match of all time. In the other semifinal, it'll be top seeded Novak Djokovic against Spaniard Roberto Bautista Agut after Djokovic won on Wednesday in just under two hours. Don't forget, you can catch Wimbledon Primetime at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Thursday on Tennis Channel. I'm Jonathan Novack.

BARTIROMO: Well, the economy firing on all cylinders, has some investors signaling a Goldilocks cycle, once again, Goldilocks, not too hot, not too cold. Stuart Varney from "VARNEY & CO." is here now. Stu. Good morning.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's my expression, I know that it was used back in the 1990s, you know, Goldilocks economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Sure. Of course.

VARNEY: Yes, I think it's a Goldilocks market right now. I mean I'll defend that position. You got good news on interest rates, I think the market's factoring in three rate cuts this year, modestly good news on China trade, profits are looking good for the second half of the year, and the economy is still pretty strong with no sign of inflation. So that's why I would call it a Goldilocks market because we hit a series of new highs yesterday, and look at the screen, left-hand side of the screen, we're going to go up, all three indicators up again first thing this morning. Dow is going to get pretty close to 27,000.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

VARNEY: I'll call it a Goldilocks market. How about you?

BARTIROMO: But you know, Stu, the market looks at what's next, what's ahead.

VARNEY: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: And now we're expecting a slowdown toward the end of the year. Yesterday, Powell said there are crosscurrents that have developed.

VARNEY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And it has to do with uncertainty over trade.

VARNEY: So he'll drop interest rates to take account of those threats on the -- on the horizon. I mean he's going to take care of the market, isn't he?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

VARNEY: I mean he -- he's guaranteeing that this market doesn't crash, or trying to.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And the question -- the question we've been asking this morning is, can a rate cut actually fix all ails? We'll see.

VARNEY: I don't think so.

BARTIROMO: Yes. There you go.

VARNEY: But that's an entire separate debate, isn't it?

BARTIROMO: All right. I think so. Stu, I know you'll have a lot more in about 12 minutes.

VARNEY: Sure thing.

BARTIROMO: We will see you then.

VARNEY: You got it.

BARTIROMO: "VARNEY & CO." begins top of the hour 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. Join Stuart after the program, but first, we are cashing in on cannabis next. We're taking you live to one of the world's largest marijuana companies for a closer look at the drug and the prospects for growth there. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. OK. So the big business of CBD, Ashley Webster is live in Smith Falls, Canada this morning with a look at Canopy Growth, one of the world's largest marijuana companies. Ashley, good morning to you. Look at that getup you have on.

ASHLEY WEBSTER, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, good morning, Maria. In fact, Canopy -- do you like this? This is a protected suit. Why? Because I'm inside one of the 47 grow rooms. I'm surrounded by marijuana plants. But if I bring in some sort of contaminant, then I could wipeout this crop, and I'd be in a lot of trouble, and I'd have a big bill to pay. So, I'm all suited up.

Canada only legalized recreational marijuana about nine months ago. And as you can see, business is booming, literally growing. But it's not just marijuana that you smoke, there's also what they called cannabinoid, that's CBD. The health benefits as a health supplement is a big business, $5 billion this year alone. But there are still questions, Maria, as to whether CBD is safe. You can get in it drinks, you can get it in all types of foods. But we spoke to a doctor who said, you know what, he has his doubts right now. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MIKHAIL VARSHAVSKI, FAMILY MEDICINE DOCTOR: Think about all these sources of CBD coming into your body. Is that safe? I, as a doctor, don't have an answer, but I err on the side of caution and say that is not ideal. We need some sort of regulation here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: Well, you know, the FDA also says it has its doubts and is not OK of the ingestion of CBD, but you can go anywhere in America and find CBD products. We spoke to the CEO of Canopy. His name is Mark Zekulin and he says he welcomes regulation. Take a listen to him.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK ZEKULIN, CEO, CANOPY GROWTH: You know, there are people selling tons of CBD products all over America right now, all over the world right now. So, you know, they have a real incentive to put a system in place to make sure that what you're buying is properly labeled, has been tested, produced to a certain standard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WEBSTER: so there you have it, Maria. They're making a huge bed canopy. It is the world's largest legal marijuana grower. They believe the United States is in the outlook in their forecast. They already have seven big facilities, including one in upstate New York where they're growing hemp. But in the meantime, as you can see, this is what they believe will be the face of the United States to come. The question is, can the Federal authorities in Washington agree with some of those states like California and Colorado and legalize marijuana and CBD for that matter across the board? We'll have to wait and see.

We're going to be here all day. We're going to show you some remarkable sites. In fact, across the street, there is a billion dollars' worth of marijuana just piled up, and the irony is, it's right next door to the police station.

BARTIROMO: What?

WEBSTER: Who would have thunk it? Back to you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Wow. And these companies have gone public. Investors are believing. I know Tilray, when it was IPO'ed, was one of the best IPOs we saw all year.

WEBSTER: Yes. Absolutely. And in fact, there has been a change here at Canopy. Bruce Linton was the original CEO. He's been on FOX Business a number of times, he kind of left suddenly. Mark Zekulin, who we spoke to as the new CEO, I asked him, "What's going on?" He said, "Bruce was the founder. He's kind of a blue-sky thinker. He's moving on to his next job. But Canopy continues to grow. You can trade it on the New York Stock Exchange. It can be traded here in Canada under weed." They believe this is the future and CBD in particular.

BARTIROMO: All right. Good symbol there. Ashley, thank you. Ashley Webster in Canada this morning. Still ahead, final thoughts from this all- star panel. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from this all-star panel. Steve Forbes.

FORBES: Watch out on the trade front. Watch out for the Fed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. For sure. James.

FREEMAN: And, you know, I wish the president would realize every other country is not China. He's made a good case that China's mistreatment of American business needs to be addressed. He ought to be seeking trade peace with everybody else.

BARTIROMO: Uh-hmm.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Again, don't be fixated on the trade deficit because U.S. prosperity, this irrelevant economic measure --

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: -- U.S. prosperity means that we will probably still have a trade deficit as we do. So, trade war, still got a trade deficit.

BARTIROMO: Hey, we're on the doorstep of second quarter earnings. We're going to start getting those numbers next week. That's going to be the driver for the market. The big banks, next week. Great show this morning, guys.

FREEMAN: Thanks.

FORBES: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much.

FREEMAN: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Steve Forbes, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins now. Stu, take it away.

VARNEY: All right. Thanks, Maria.

urn:contentItem:5WJD-YG91-JBHT-D38B-00000-00SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisSEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESSLanhamFULL TEXT

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN) IS INTERVIEWED ON FOX BUSINESS

JULY 11, 2019

SPEAKERS: SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST

[*] MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Joining me right now is Tennessee senator, member of the Judiciary and Armed Services Committee is Marsha Blackburn.

Senator, it's good to see you this morning.

SEN. MARSHA BLACKBURN (R-TN): Good to see you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks so much for joining me.

BLACKBURN: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: So we're -- we're talking about this White House summit. You're urging big tech to protect young children. What do you want to see out of big technology?

BLACKBURN: What I would like to see out of big tech is some responsibility and accountability. And, Maria, they go in and subjectively manipulate their algorithms and then it opens the doors that it ought not to children, like the SnapChat letter that I sent this week deals with the way pornography is made public on their site. And this is made available. The ratings are wrong on these apps. Children are seeing this. They need to adjust those ratings. And, also, parents need to be aware. You need to give parents the tools to block this.

These videos that are deleted, this becomes a child predator's dream for contacting these children. And there are several cases where pedophiles have used SnapChat to contact and to coerce these children.

BARTIROMO: Wow, that's unbelievable. You know, it --

BLACKBURN: It is unbelievable.

BARTIROMO: It feels like this is one issue big tech hits at both corners and both sides of the aisle. You've got people like Elizabeth Warren and Ted Cruz both saying that they want to break these companies up. Do you want to see breakups of some of these large companies that are today, as you know, more powerful than we've ever -- we've ever known?

BLACKBURN: Yes. Well, I think where we start is with privacy issue. And yesterday Chris Hughes, who was the co-founder of FaceBook, was in my office and we had a very productive discussion about how you deal with privacy and giving consumers the tool box to protect, as I term it, their virtual you, themselves online. So you start with privacy and data security. You look at how the social media giants are prioritizing their content over content that should be readily available online. And I'm going to have a meeting later today with CEOs of Yelp concerning this issue because they're conducting -- Google prioritizes their content.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: So that determines what people see, what they have access to. We're also going to look at censorship and anti-trust and say, do these companies need to reposition themselves? But I think first you look at the privacy issue and you determine how that forces the media companies to adjust their business model. Right now they are -- they built their business model on a no holds barred. They do not have to inform you that they are taking your data, that they are mining your data, that they are positioning your data to be sold to the highest bidder who is going to market back to you or is going to go through and sift your data and then determine what they want to push forward to you in -- in the method of videos or articles. It's like with YouTube.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: You look at one video then they fill a stream with similar videos.

BARTIROMO: So, real quick, we -- I want to move on to the border --

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But let me -- let me end this here on this because when I spoke with the president a couple of weeks ago, he side, look, we might need legislation which will spur competition.

BLACKBURN: Correct.

BARTIROMO: Do you want to see regulation for these companies?

BLACKBURN: The Browser Act is legislation that deals with the privacy issue that I introduced in the House. I have reintroduced that in the Senate. And we are working to move that forward to get those guardrails in place and to do that first, like touch --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: Like touch, but to put those parameters in place.

BARTIROMO: Understood.

All right, let me move to the -- the crisis at the border, senator, because immigration and customs enforcement agents are reportedly preparing to conduct raids beginning Sunday to arrest thousands of illegal immigrants across the country. The move coming weeks after President Trump said that the operation was first being delayed. You're headed to the southern border with Vice President Mike Pence tomorrow.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What are you expecting? And do you think we're ever going to get our arms around these loopholes that are encouraging so many illegals migrants to flood the border?

BLACKBURN: Right. The -- the thing is, we have to get our hands around the loopholes, and we have to plug these loopholes, if you will, and make certain that those who are coming to our country come here legally. The Border Patrol -- I was down there a couple of months ago and they are in desperate need of some help. And my hope is that our Democrat colleagues will begin to work with us to give the Border Patrol the three things they continue to say they need. They have been saying this for 20 years. Give them a barrier, give them appropriate technology, give them more officers, agents and judges to deal with this issue.

BARTIROMO: Yes, but let's be honest, they don't want the president to have a victory. They -- they -- I mean some people on the Democrats side hate him so much that they're just going to try to make a point and not do anything about this issue.

BLACKBURN: Maria, I --

BARTIROMO: Do you really see anything getting done?

BLACKBURN: Yes, I've got to tell you, they need to get over their pettiness and they need to put this nation and our sovereignty and the protection of the American people first.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I understand.

BLACKBURN: They need to -- they need to stop this human trafficking, sex trafficking, drug trafficking that is taking place on our border.

Every town's a border town. Every state's a border state --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: Because of the drugs and the human trafficking coming through. They need to get over themselves.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because all these people are --

BARTIROMO: That lost that election.

BARTIROMO: Right.

BLACKBURN: They need to work for the good of the American people.

BARTIROMO: All these people are coming to the border and facing these situations where, before they even get to the border, they've got to deal with the drug lords. So there's that.

BLACKBURN: That's right.

BARTIROMO: And -- and then, you know, they don't want to do anything there, but there's also an issue on trade. So let me asks about USMCA.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: What -- what is the likelihood that the -- that the bill comes to the floor for a vote in the fall?

BLACKBURN: The votes are there. If Pelosi were to put it on the floor today, it would pass.

BARTIROMO: So why isn't she?

BLACKBURN: I think that there again you're looking at people that say, well, do we want to give Donald Trump a victory? Give the American people a victory!

BARTIROMO: Yes.

BLACKBURN: The unions are for this. The farmers are for this. Come on, guys, put it on the floor and call a vote.

BARTIROMO: All right, so you don't know. You don't know is the answering if she's going to bring it to the floor by the fall, is that what you're saying?

BLACKBURN: She should bring it to the fall next -- to the floor next week.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Exactly.

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: OK, let -- let me ask you about China.

BLACKBURN: Sure.

BARTIROMO: Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer is going to be meeting with members to discuss USMCA. I spoke with Vice President Mike Pence's chief of staff, Marc Short, on the program yesterday --

BLACKBURN: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And he is the one who said it's probably going to come to the floor in the fall. What's plan b if -- if -- if she doesn't bring it to the floor? I mean could that happen that she actually doesn't bring it to the floor?

BLACKBURN: I think she will see what happened to the border funding bill, the week before last, where you will see the moderates in her caucus say, come on, Nancy, let's get with it, let's get this job done. And when you have the unions and so many of the trade groups all saying USMCA let's push it forward, she needs to say -- she and Steny need to say, let's put it on the floor and call the vote. Let the chips fall where they may. Let Nancy and Steny declare victory by being able to move something forward. We need to get this thing done. When it comes to China, we're going to continue to encourage holding that line against Huawei. China will steal our intellectual property. They will embed chips and build Huawei as a spy network in that equipment and consumer products. We need to make certain that we deal with that issue and not give them an inch. We know what they're up to.

BARTIROMO: Well, you certainly have been keeping -- and the president has been keeping his -- his -- his boots on the neck of -- of the Chinese on this issue for sure.

BLACKBURN: Yes. Yes.

BARTIROMO: Senator, it's good to see you, as always. Thanks so much.

BLACKBURN: Good to see you. Thanks.

BARTIROMO: Marsha Blackburn joining us there.

END

urn:contentItem:60XM-D1P1-F0YC-N04K-00000-00Sen. Menendez Introduces Bill to Stop Fraudulent Online Gun Sales2020-09-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisSen. Menendez Introduces Bill to Stop Fraudulent Online Gun Sales

Washington: Office of the Senator Bob Menendez has issued the following news release:

U.S Senators Bob Menendez (D-N.J ), who has continually called out Facebook for its failure to monitor and enforce its own ban on gun sales, and Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) today introduced the Stop Online Fraudulent Sales of Firearms Act that would prevent gun sellers from circumventing technology companies’ terms of service by making it illegal to fraudulently sell firearms and ammunition online.

“The fact is, no matter how many times big tech companies claim they’re cracking down on illegal online firearm sales, determined gun sellers and buyers find new ways to get around it,” Sen. Menendez said. “With this bill, we are making very clear to gun sellers who are caught illegally moving their weapons online: if you make the sale, you will pay the price.”

“While some technology companies have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their websites, the problem persists,” Sen. Feinstein said. “Our bill would make it illegal for gun sellers to circumvent websites’ terms of service and continue the underground proliferation of firearms. It’s part of a larger effort that needs to be taken to stop the plague of gun violence in our communities.”

“Internet marketplaces like Facebook are the virtual dark alley where unscrupulous gun sellers go to meet dangerous individuals who are trying to get their hands on a firearm,” said John Feinblatt, President of Everytown for Gun Safety. “Stopping these illegal sales would save lives, and we applaud Senator Feinstein for introducing legislation to do exactly that.”

“Overwhelming majorities of Americans support policies that ensure that individuals who should not possess firearms are not able to purchase them, including online,”said Kris Brown, President of Brady. “Brady is grateful to Senators Feinstein and Menendez for addressing a dangerous practice of falsely advertising firearm sales online. Such sales are designed to circumvent the regulations that help keep our families and communities safe. This is a common-sense fix to a growing problem that applies the spirit of our nation's existing gun safety laws to novel, 21st century issues.”

Although technology giants like Facebook have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their platforms, sellers have consistently found ways, like misrepresenting guns as other items, to circumvent those restrictions.

Last month, Facebook reported it had removed 1.3 million pieces of content related to firearms between April and June 2020 from its platforms.

urn:contentItem:60XM-W4H1-F12F-F25V-00000-00SEN. MENENDEZ INTRODUCES BILL TO STOP FRAUDULENT ONLINE GUN SALES2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisSEN. MENENDEZ INTRODUCES BILL TO STOP FRAUDULENT ONLINE GUN SALES

WASHINGTON, DC, Sept. 24 -- The office of Sen. Bob Menendez issued the following press release:

U.S. Senators Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), who has continually called out Facebook for its failure to monitor and enforce its own ban on gun sales (https://www.menendez.senate.gov/news-and-events/press/menendez-markey-and-colleagues-blast-facebooks-continued-failure-to-monitor-and-enforce-gun-sales-ban), and Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) today introduced the Stop Online Fraudulent Sales of Firearms Act (https://www.menendez.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/stop-online-fraudulent-sales-of-firearms-act%202020.pdf) that would prevent gun sellers from circumventing technology companies' terms of service by making it illegal to fraudulently sell firearms and ammunition online.

"The fact is, no matter how many times big tech companies claim they're cracking down on illegal online firearm sales, determined gun sellers and buyers find new ways to get around it," Sen. Menendez said. "With this bill, we are making very clear to gun sellers who are caught illegally moving their weapons online: if you make the sale, you will pay the price."

"While some technology companies have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their websites, the problem persists," Sen. Feinstein said. "Our bill would make it illegal for gun sellers to circumvent websites' terms of service and continue the underground proliferation of firearms. It's part of a larger effort that needs to be taken to stop the plague of gun violence in our communities."

"Internet marketplaces like Facebook are the virtual dark alley where unscrupulous gun sellers go to meet dangerous individuals who are trying to get their hands on a firearm," said John Feinblatt, President of Everytown for Gun Safety. "Stopping these illegal sales would save lives, and we applaud Senator Feinstein for introducing legislation to do exactly that."

"Overwhelming majorities of Americans support policies that ensure that individuals who should not possess firearms are not able to purchase them, including online,"said Kris Brown, President of Brady. "Brady is grateful to Senators Feinstein and Menendez for addressing a dangerous practice of falsely advertising firearm sales online. Such sales are designed to circumvent the regulations that help keep our families and communities safe. This is a common-sense fix to a growing problem that applies the spirit of our nation's existing gun safety laws to novel, 21st century issues."

Although technology giants like Facebook have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their platforms, sellers have consistently found ways, like misrepresenting guns as other items, to circumvent those restrictions.

Last month, Facebook reported it had removed 1.3 million pieces of content related to firearms between April and June 2020 from its platforms. For any query with respect to this article or any other content requirement, please contact Editor at contentservices@htlive.com

Robert Menendez (D-NJ) News Release2020-09-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:24:14ZLexisNexisU.S. SENATE DOCUMENTSSen. Menendez Introduces Bill to Stop Fraudulent Online Gun SalesSen. Robert Menendez (D-NJ) News Release

WASHINGTON, D.C.-- U.S. Senators Bob Menendez (D-N.J.), who has continually called out Facebook for its failure to monitor and enforce its own ban on gun sales, and Dianne Feinstein (D-Calif.) today introduced the Stop Online Fraudulent Sales of Firearms Act that would prevent gun sellers from circumventing technology companies' terms of service by making it illegal to fraudulently sell firearms and ammunition online.

"The fact is, no matter how many times big tech companies claim they're cracking down on illegal online firearm sales, determined gun sellers and buyers find new ways to get around it," Sen. Menendez said. "With this bill, we are making very clear to gun sellers who are caught illegally moving their weapons online: if you make the sale, you will pay the price."

"While some technology companies have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their websites, the problem persists," Sen. Feinstein said. "Our bill would make it illegal for gun sellers to circumvent websites' terms of service and continue the underground proliferation of firearms. It's part of a larger effort that needs to be taken to stop the plague of gun violence in our communities."

"Internet marketplaces like Facebook are the virtual dark alley where unscrupulous gun sellers go to meet dangerous individuals who are trying to get their hands on a firearm," said John Feinblatt, President of Everytown for Gun Safety. "Stopping these illegal sales would save lives, and we applaud Senator Feinstein for introducing legislation to do exactly that."

"Overwhelming majorities of Americans support policies that ensure that individuals who should not possess firearms are not able to purchase them, including online,"said Kris Brown, President of Brady. "Brady is grateful to Senators Feinstein and Menendez for addressing a dangerous practice of falsely advertising firearm sales online. Such sales are designed to circumvent the regulations that help keep our families and communities safe. This is a common-sense fix to a growing problem that applies the spirit of our nation's existing gun safety laws to novel, 21st century issues."

Although technology giants like Facebook have banned selling firearms and ammunition on their platforms, sellers have consistently found ways, like misrepresenting guns as other items, to circumvent those restrictions.

Last month, Facebook reported it had removed 1.3 million pieces of content related to firearms between April and June 2020 from its platforms.

Read this original document at: https://www.menendez.senate.gov/news-and-events/press/sen-menendez-introduces-bill-to-stop-fraudulent-online-gun-sales
